Title: Telemetry store settings
Body: This is a pull request for the ability to store parameters in flash  so that after a reboot these parameters can be read in the initialization stage of the settings.  Overview: - persistent_settings.xml is a file that adds a persistence tab to the gcs so the store function can be triggered. - settings.c added a check that the store function cannot be triggered in flight. The regular parameter updates however will still continue to work  so one can update the parameters as usual  they just won't be saved until the user lands the aircraft and then clicks store.  - the airframe shows how persistent storage functions are actually added to the code. Without the USE_PERSISTENT_SETTINGS define  the storage functions won't be added to the compilation stage. - a minor update to the radio file  which uses always 8 channels and not 7. - added the jsbsim xml file for the simulator. - added a script to start flightgear with a mikrokopter.  Without any "persistent=true" attributes in any settings file  the persistent storage structure remains empty and the result of writing will be 0 (also in the UI). So  the next question is which parameters in the config files will need to be made persistent. Instead of going ahead and proposing the changes in a couple of changed files  I will open this topic on the mailing list on how to approach this subject.  Testing: - I added persistent=true to one file temporarily  recompiled and reloaded the code. Then I verified the function gets called and the flash memory is updated. - I then stopped all processes  reflashed and rebooted the boards and restarted all processes. - Then I went into the GCS  noticed the default value A for the specific parameter  modified that to value B  clicked the tick mark to upload this value  then clicked the Store function  remembering the value B.  - I verified the "store" button changed from 0. to "Store" (which means the store was successful). - Then I killed all processes  removed power from the boards and restarted everything. - I waited for the server process to accumulate the new settings (these get sent by telemetry in an iterative process).  - Then I went into settings and verified the value of that specific parameter  which appeared as value B.  Associated with issue #29

Title: Telemetry functions
Body: Replacing the old macros with functions. This is done by introducing a generic transport structure and a generic device structure. It is only a small step on purpose  changing everything at once usually fails.  There is no functional changes  except that the transport and device for periodic function is passed as an argument  which will allow to create a telemetry task for logging in parallel of the normal telemetry (soon).  We now have: - 4 transports (pprz  pprzlog  xbee  ivy) - 5 devices (uart  usb_uart  sdio(chibios)  udp  w5100)  This was tested on: - lpc (pprz) - stm32f4 (pprz  pprzlog  xbee) - sim/nps (ivy)

Title: module to use radio channel as remote camera trigger
Body: ``` new file:   conf/modules/digital_cam_shoot_rc.xml new file:   sw/airborne/modules/digital_cam/dc_shoot_rc.c new file:   sw/airborne/modules/digital_cam/dc_shoot_rc.h ```

Title: messages add INFO_MSG and with printing to GCS console
Body: Intention is to be able to send info/debug messages via telemetry and see them in messages and the GCS console. E.g.  ``` c const char *str = "test foo"; DOWNLINK_SEND_INFO_MSG(DefaultChannel  DefaultDevice  strlen(str)  str); ```  Added a string_of_chars function to pretty print char arrays as strings so you get `test` instead of `|t e s t|` in the GCS console and messages app. (My OCaml fu is not very strong  so how that is done is probably not the nicest way).  Bind to the INFO_MSG in live and log_and_say to console.

Title: JTAG latest proven blackmagic firmware
Body: should be part of paparazzi with easy update function

Title: Master eduardo
Body: added conversion from lat lon to local coordinate on mission elements that work with LLA coordinate system.  Added option SIDE_UP option to drotek imu. added startup mode to cam_roll module

Title: tests option to show warnings even if successfully compiled
Body: Examples on how to test compile all aircrafts/targets in your current conf.xml: with parallel compilation and showing full output during compilation  ``` J=AUTO prove tests/examples -v ```  only showing full compile output if there has been an error  if there were warnings only print those  ``` SHOW_WARNINGS_ONLY=1 prove test/examples ```  with parallel compilation and treating all warnings as errors:  ``` J=AUTO USER_CFLAGS=-Werror prove tests/examples ```

Title: math some cleanup and fixes for fixedpoint functions
Body: - int32_sqrt returns an unsigned int - int32_sqrt takes an unsigned int as argument - state interface: speed_norm_i is unsigned - unsigned nav_leg_length - fix int32_vec2_normalize

Title: radio control spektrum also usable for intermcu
Body: Alternative to #843  You have to add the radio_control subsystem to the ap target as well in order to get the `RADIO_CONTROL_TYPE_H` define to load the correct implementation header so we get the `RADIO_CONTROL_NB_CHANNEL`. For spektrum you might have to define `RADIO_CONTROL_NB_CHANNEL` in your airframe file to something less than 10 to use it with the uart inter_mcu.

Title: peripherals mpu60x0 use gcc pragma to ignore cast qual warnings
Body: The buffer is volatile  since filled from ISR... But we know it's ok to use it here so we silence the warning.  Also there is a bug in some gcc version that incorrectly reports this as `peripherals/mpu60x0_spi.c:118:33: warning: cast discards '__attribute__((noreturn))' qualifier from pointer target type [-Wcast-qual]` see https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=55383

Title: Driver for the MPU9250
Body: Includes the driver peripheral (i2c and spi)  the imu implementation (i2c) and a test module (i2c). When using i2c driver  the magnetometer ak8963 is also used (using @fvantienen's driver with small fix).

Title: Remove array delimiters on Ivy messages
Body: - [ocaml] use quotes for char arrays - char[] are now treated as 'real' strings - no more delimiters for other arrays (where space characters should not   appear)  From #929   Up to now arrays sent on the Ivy bus had a `|` delimiter and you had e.g. `|1 23 4 5|` and `|f o o   b a r|`. Now it would be `1 23 4 5` and `"foo bar"`.  Todo: - [x] backwards compatibility reading arrays in old format e.g. from old logs - [x] update all other progs that read ivy messages with arrays which don't use the OCaml lib (C  python...)

Title: Air data improvements and conversion to module
Body: Converts air_data to a module and adds: - math functions for QNH  etc. from #837  - subscribe to BARO_DIFF via ABI - subscribe to TEMPERATURE via ABI - calculate airspeed from differential pressure if enabled (default) - calculate QNH from abs pressure and altitude (enabled by default) - calculate AMSL from baro pressure and QNH (disabled by default) - calculate true airspeed (TAS) from equivalent airspeed (EAS) using a `tas_factor` (with default to 1.0) - calculate `tas_factor` from ISA model and current pressure and temperature (enabled by default)  I think this is a better place to handle QNH than the qnh.xml module from #837   QNH and TAS not tested in real flight so far...

Title: modules add airspeed_ms45xx_i2c module
Body: By default a differential pressure sensor with range of 5psi is set  not sure if that makes sense.  Untested  please also check if the default airspeed scale is correct.  Should be a better implementation of #708

Title: radio_control spektrum for nps sim
Body: Works in NPS and OCaml sim in quick test.  OCaml sim always uses the radio.xml file and sends ppm values in usec. So for the time beeing you need to use the spektrum.xml radio file for the sim target if you really want to use the RC in the simple OCaml sim.  closes #503

Title: flight_plan call functions once without checking return value for looping
Body: _set_ needs a variable name and _call_ needs a function that returns a bool. There is no elegant solution for handlers  while paparazzi has more and more handlers. So we introduce the flightplan  _handle fun=KillThrottle()_ block. It does also not cause a delay and moves to the next statement.

Title: Math functions
Body: Convert quite a few math macros to functions. This should make the code easier to use  debug and wrap externally. Additionally code size probably reduces since it's not all inline anymore...  Also cleaned up all the headers and added `extern "C"` to all the header files the math lib can easier be used in C++ applications.  So far the macros all still exist and call the respective functions for backwards compatibility.

Title: UART and GPS bugs
Body: - Fix a bug in the UART weak handlers I introduced incorrectly. Hopefully this fixes some of the problems with the AR.Drone 2 (didn't test it yet  will do tomorrow) - Fix a bug in the NMEA parser  made a small error in a pointer to an integer.

Title: uart Fix weak handler
Body: Fix uart handler correctly with use of weak function.

Title: tests skeleton for testing math lib with libtap
Body: using [libtap](https://github.com/zorgnax/libtap) to create a [TAP](http://testanything.org) (TestAnythingProtocol) producer. You can also run the test (if already compiled) with prove:  ``` prove --exec '' tests/math/test_pprz_math.run ```  Proposal and starting point for attacking #954

Title: omap basic spi driver
Body: totally untested...  As a starting point for review and testing...

Title: messages possibility to add descriptions
Body: Wonder why I never added this earlier as I thought about it like a gazillion times already....  Of course we still need to make use of that and actually fill in more descriptions  but that can be done bit by bit...

Title: modules messages mission LLA waypoints in 1e7deg instead of float
Body: A 32bit float has 23bits for the mantissa  which is a bit more than 7 digits. Since you already use 3 digits to represent the part to the left of the decimal point  that leaves about 4 digits for the rest.. So in the worst case of 180deg you have a resolution of only ~3m!  With 1e7deg 32bit int you get ~1cm resolution.  addresses first part of #984

Title: submodules updated to a new chibios repository
Body: https://github.com/ChibiOS/ChibiOS-RT.git is not a valid repository anomore  the latest (stable) version of chibios (2.6.2) is available at https://github.com/ChibiOS/ChibiOS-gitmain.git  Hopefully it still works with the chibios code for data logging (master branch)  rt_paparazzi currently uses a separate repository of ChibiOS (https://github.com/podhrmic/ChibiOS-RT.git  also version 2.6.2).

Title: radio_control cleanup channel defines
Body: - PPM: remove PPM_NB_CHANNEL define an always decode RADIO_CTL_NB (number of channels in radio.xml) - PPM: the actually used/needed channels RADIO_CONTROL_NB_CHANNEL default to RADIO_CTL_NB but can be overwritten by user   e.g. to use less channels for intermcu - SBUS: only provide a default for RADIO_CONTROL_NB_CHANNEL - error if RADIO_CONTROL_NB_CHANNEL > max available channels  As far as I can discern this should finally make it possible to override the actually used RADIO_CONTROL_NB_CHANNEL from the airframe file (e.g. to transfer less via intermcu) while still using the proper number of channels for parsing. So with this it looks like the separate RADIO_CONTROL_USED_NB_CHANNELS as proposed in #973 is not needed.  Untested on real hardware...

Body: Contains: - hw dependent implementation (arch/stm32/) - examples:   - serial console over USB   - serial port  sending of large amount of data  - based on libopencm3 example  Known issues: - on some USB Hubs the device seems to have hard time to enumerate - it also doesn't enumerate on Gumstix overo (`device descriptor read/64  error`)  _[ 6907.807027] usb 2-1.5.4: device descriptor read/64  error -110 [ 6918.001890] usb 2-1.5.4: device descriptor read/64  error -110 [ 6918.190123] usb 2-1.5.4: new full-speed USB device number 86 using ehci-pci [ 6928.280821] usb 2-1.5.4: device descriptor read/64  error -110 [ 6928.469443] usb 2-1.5.4: device descriptor read/64  error 2 [ 6928.657313] usb 2-1.5.4: new full-speed USB device number 87 using ehci-pci [ 6928.679084] usb 2-1.5.4: device descriptor read/8  error -75 [ 6928.797360] usb 2-1.5.4: device descriptor read/all  error 8 [ 6928.885710] usb 2-1.5.4: new full-speed USB device number 88 using ehci-pci [ 6928.906215] usb 2-1.5.4: device descriptor read/all  error 8 [ 6928.908962] hub 2-1.5:1.0: unable to enumerate USB device on port 4 [ 6954.882391] usb 3-2: new full-speed USB device number 2 using xhci_hcd [ 6954.901079] usb 3-2: New USB device found  idVendor=0483  idProduct=5740 [ 6954.901090] usb 3-2: New USB device strings: Mfr=1  Product=2  SerialNumber=3 [ 6954.901096] usb 3-2: Product: CDC-ACM Demo Lia [ 6954.901101] usb 3-2: Manufacturer: Black Sphere Technologies [ 6954.901106] usb 3-2: SerialNumber: DEMO [ 6954.901326] usb 3-2: ep 0x83 - rounding interval to 1024 microframes  ep desc says 2040 microframes [ 6954.901713] cdc_acm 3-2:1.0: This device cannot do calls on its own. It is not a modem. [ 6954.901764] cdc_acm 3-2:1.0: ttyACM2: USB ACM device [ 7018.181917] usb 3-2: USB disconnect  device number 2_ ` This seems to be related to either libopencm3 drivers  because I have also STM library based implementation of CDC device and that works every time (both on PC and Overo).  Necessary step towards USB telemetry. That is giving me hard time because of all macros that are involved.

Universal CRC nonCRC stm32_mem tool

Title: select_conf Now also selects control_panel
Body: Finally you can now also commit you own `control_panel.xml` and switch between versions. - Several bugfixes and implemented todo's - Although more buttons are added  design reviewed to be lighter

Title: build default to parallel make for aircrafts
Body: Since parallel compilation of airframes seems to work without problems and is quite a bit faster  make it the default...  Previously you had to pass `J=AUTO` as environment variable (to use auto-detected number of cpus). You can still pass `J=4` to set it to 4 jobs explicitly or `J=1` for serial compilation.

Title: airborne rename arch omap to arch linux
Body: Closes #980

Title: rotorcraft force MODE_STARTUP instead of KILL until ahrs is aligned
Body: - Go to MODE_STARTUP (which defaults to AP_MODE_KILL) instead of AP_MODE_KILL as long as the ahrs is not aligned. - Remove AUTOPILOT_DISABLE_AHRS_KILL from all example airframes (but kept the functionality for now).  MODE_STARTUP is set to AP_MODE_NAV for the autonomous (without RC) ARDrone2. Without AUTOPILOT_DISABLE_AHRS_KILL it will force MODE_STARTUP until the ahrs is aligned  but still not allow to turn on the motors (as that also checks for ahrs_is_aligned).  As far as I can see this should solve #964 as long as you don't have AUTOPILOT_DISABLE_AHRS_KILL defined.

Title: simulator OCaml sim simulate sys_time
Body: Call the sys_tick_handler from the OCaml sim.  Since the simple OCaml sim has the PERIODIC_FREQUENCY hardcoded  I also added some warnings if you have different frequencies set for the sim target in your airframe file.  Worked for me in a quick test and should fix #962

Title: New module Temperature ADC
Body: Added temperature driver for analog sensors (LM35 and 100k NTC) some correction to digital_cam module

Title: pass deltaT to ahrs ins propagation
Body: Starts making it possible to calculate dt instead of using AHRS|INS_PROPAGATE_FREQUENCY. That is already done now for rotorcraft firmware  for fixedwings it is still using the defined freq. The fixedwing ins_alt_float now uses the real dt for alt_kalman update from baro or gps. Should be cleaner like this and less prone to misconfiguration  possible drawback however is that you get some more jitter on the DT.  Not really properly taken into account for: - int_cmpl_euler: this is very ugly and still has F_UPDATE 512Hz hardcoded  but nobody should use this one anyway.. - float_cmpl and int_cmpl_quat: still use AHRS_PROPAGATE_FREQUENCY to set the gains...  Also should we put bounds on the dt that is calculated from sys_time (e.g. in the baro and gps update of ins_alt_float)?

Title: actuators ESC32 can support
Body: Driver for the Autoquad ESC32 motor controllers via CAN.  Apparently the configuration of which way they turn doesn't work yet.

Body: The string wasn't properly terminated before thus often showing garbage characters at the end.

Title: stm32 Usb tunnel
Body: - add usb_tunnel for stm32 - replace usb_tunnel_0 and usb_tunnel_1 targets on lpc with one usb_tunnel that is configurable - cleanup setup makefile - rename VCOM_transmit_message to VCOM_send_message - check if usb is connected in putchar and send_message  Open questions/todo: - [x] use one usb_tunnel for both stm32 and lpc (only functional difference is currently the minimum blink time on lpc) - [x] really keep the setup firmware? Or just put the few targets we have there also in test_progs?

Title: rotorcraft allow to turn off motors in failsafe mode
Body: Allow arming/disarming motor as long as not in KILL mode and ahrs is aligned.  should close #988

Title: modules start pimping dependencies
Body: Start working on #940  This replaces  ``` xml <depend require="foo|bar" conflict="baz"/> ```  with  ``` xml <depends>foo bar</depends> <conflicts>baz</conflicts> ```  and now allows to specify OR dependencies with | (pipe) similaro to Debian depends:  ``` xml <depends>foo bar this|that</depends> ```  which would depend on: foo AND bar AND (this OR that)

Title: state interface update stateCalcPositionLla_i
Body: Since LLA in float has bad precision  make this the last choice... So we mostly first convert to ECEF and then use lla_of_ecef_i which provides higher precision but is currently using the double function internally.  Also add misssing conversions from ENU and some first tests...

Title: modules clean up digital cam
Body: Starting to solve #867 and clean digital cam up a bit.. - **replace meter grid by proper distance autoshoot**:   Previously DC_AUTOSHOOT_DISTANCE would shoot on a 100m UTM north distance grid  seems like nobody actually used that or found this useful.   So changing this to "proper" distance based autoshoot  where we shoot the next pic  if `dc_autoshoot_distance_interval` is greater than distance to last saved shot position.  Todo: - [x] remove `dc_probing` ? - [x] choose _one_ coordinate system and harmonize DC_\* messages (LLA chosen) - [x] actually test with rotorcrafts (works in sim)

I'll just have a look and @alonsoac request to select all array elements at once.

Title: Polyosam add features
Body: Added options to - start first sweep x meter from polygon border - configure the entry circle radius - configured the min turn radius  Now the last turn can be a half sweep back or half seep forward if the distance from last turn is less than full sweep distance.  All this modification is made to use this module with more confidence in professional photogrammetry.

Title: Ardrone2 magnetofixfix
Body: A tested fix on four different ARdrone2's and for day on end to find a fix. Restyled to PPRZ codestyle with astyle script included with PPRZ that give a little more changes than normal.  Removed telemetry for now  since it hung after that inclusion several times  no clue why. If needed can be re-added after a renewed testing round.

Title: rotorcraft fix USE_KILL_SWITCH_FOR_MOTOR_ARMING
Body: alternative to #1035   Arming with kill switch was broken since #983

Title: autopilot unkill in manual was not possible when
Body: initially there is AP_MODE_STARTING which typically is AP_MODE_KILL then it is not possible to unkill with RC

Title: Transition
Body: Added forward mode and 'care free' mode. Also made it possible to not use the reference model in the control  as it is not working out for me. I find it to be very sensitive and not robust if you really want to make the feedforward work.   I changed the way the current yaw is determined to avoid switching beyond 90 degrees  as this would be unwanted when transitioning (and for quads as well). The other option I considered was changing the BODY_TO_IMU rotation  but I found this to be less clear  for instance when reviewing the logs.  Any comments are welcome!

Title: Guidance attitude
Body: Simplified the guidance setpoint calculation

Title: attitude quat int integrator changed
Body: This should fix two things: the integrator could previously wrap around because it was an actual quaternion. Upon an error it would first go up to ~32000 and then if the error persisted go down again. This is obviously unwanted. I changed to a regular sum of each of the error values.  For the ground detection  the autopilot_ground_detected was reset before the nav would run and trigger the ground detect exception  since the nav stuff runs on a lower frequency. Autopilot_ground_detected should be reset in the nav function anyway.

Title: always allow switching to MODE_MANUAL via RC even during HOME or FAILSAFE
Body: Always allow switching to `MODE_MANUAL` via RC  even if in HOME or FAILSAFE mode. So to whatever that is defined to in the airframe file (usually `AP_MODE_ATTITUDE_DIRECT`)

Outback2014 airframe

Spelling correction

Title: server write paparzzi_version as comment at beginning of log
Body: Writes an xml comment at the beginning of the *.log file  e.g. `<!-- logged with paparazzi_version v5.3.2_testing-1-gbdf9a8f -->`

Title: airborne add pprz_version and send it with BOOT
Body: At build time define the Paparazzi version and git sha1 and make that usable in airborne code. The BOOT message now contains the version encoded in uint16_t as `(PPRZ_VER_MAJOR * 100 + PPRZ_VER_MINOR * 10 + PPRZ_VER_PATCH)` which is fine as long as we don't have one of these fields with a value higher than 10.

Title: Add FrSky X9D X8R SBus
ground_segment fix green darkgreen change
Body: OMG  I finally upgraded from Ubuntu 12.04 and noticed that the green color changed and made everything less readable...  Since tcl8.6 "green" refers to same color as "darkgreen" (to the one used in web) and the former "green" is now "lime"... But "lime" is not available in older versions  so hardcode the color to `#00ff00`

Title: messages add AUTOPILOT_VERSION
Body: Proposal on adding an `AUTOPILOT_VERSION` message  see also #1048 for previous discussion on this...  Finally merged state:  The AUTOPILOT_VERSION message contains: - the version encoded as integer with `MAJOR * 10000 + MINOR * 100 + PATCH` - the complete version string as returned by paparazzi_version  This message is sent once at startup of the autopilot  but can also be registered like any normal telemetry message by adding it to the telemetry airframe file.  The version string is also displayed in the GCS alert window (once per aircraft  unless it changes)...  Also the "build version" is not written to `var/build_version.txt` and the server also writes it to the log.  When building an aircraft it will now warn if the last build version differs from current version. It only checks if the current version number (e.g. 5.3.2) is contained in the full build version string. So it will warn if you changed branches to a different version  but not after e.g. committing only a airframe config change.  You can also run `make print_version` to show the current version (and the warning if build version differs).

Title: Update locm3 to get usb control callback fix for luftboot

Title: fixes to gcs flight plan editor
Body: Fixes for issue #927  - deleting a wp from Waypoint Edit dialog or from XML editor does not remove the item from the georefs menus - changing the name of a wp in xml editor or in dialog does not update the menus - closing a flight plan does not clear the menus - opening a different plan after closing the first does not work because fit to window keeps trying to fix wp from closed fp  Other changes - keep map center when zooming with the spin button - When the georef is set to a wp and the mouse is moved to a different UTM zone it would no longer update the distance. Now it shows an error message. TODO: fix so that it works across utm zones.  NOT Fixed - creating a new wp by inserting a new xml item or by copying an existing item does not add the wp to the window or the menus - deleting a wp does not remove it from sectors - changing the name of a wp does not update the sectors

Title: luftboot Added support for luftboot like bootloader for Lisa MX
Body: (the bootloader itself is in ext repository  this is only support in pprzi code) Tested on Lisa MX.

Title: build use same float_abi for linking as for compiling
Body: Make sure we link with same float abi (softfp  vfp) as we compile. This _should_ fix errors like  ``` /usr/bin/ld: error: ap.elf uses VFP register arguments  foo.o does not /usr/bin/ld: failed to merge target specific data of file foo.o ```  Not tested...

Title: fix re added brackets for correct transition offset handling
Body: These brackets were kind of important... without them the transition offset is twice as large. For me this resulted in a nose down to the ground and crash.  Was broken by f28c3615a4d85103227e3423ad237105dfd18c8b

Title: airspeed Added MS45XX driver for airspeed
Body: The SCALE is just random  so needs to be set to a more representative value. Also not sure if IIR is correctly implemented and the best solution?

Title: datalink Fix specific UDP datalink to transparent
Body: The UDP telemetry used transparent as packaging and was just a copy with specific Transmit and Receive functions implemented. This way you can use UDP also for other purposes and the transparent packaging isn't duplicated.

Title: Ivy to redis
Body: This is a little script that subscribes to the ivy bus and pushes all messages through redis. Redis is a very fast keystore of various data types with a very simple client interface and also offers a pub/sub mechanism with key matching of any length. This page shows how it works: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/redis/  Other converters like UDP servers exist  but that requires clients to also implement socket level constructs and you don't get any additional logic with those. It's also better to initiate the connection from the client. There are many client libraries available for redis  so that it's possible to interface with paparazzi from a host of languages or environments  even web browsers if you set up a node.js server. Packages that do that exist.  The main reason why I wrote this script is because I want to improve the android tablet client and make a simpler ground control for non-experienced and non-engineer users. Redis then allows me to pick which messages are transferred over either bluetooth/wifi  so that resources are better utilized.  Messages are also "set"  as a key in the keystore  which means that clients connecting later can inspect the values of settings at any point in time and don't need to request or wait for them.  Notes:  - I copied the interface code from the messages_tool.py script in sw/lib/python  because that code converts the ac_id to an int. I also wanted to publish the ground.\* messages and it was giving a ValueError. I'll make an issue about this so it can be discussed and this code removed to use the messages_tool one. It probably needs an option to select which ac_id message type should be used for the callback. - All messages are published to redis  but also "set" as a key value. It overwrites every last one that was set  so this only really works for settings. Messages like "WP_MOVED" get overwritten  but those should be subscribed to anyway (alternatives exist  like adding them to a queue  so the last x can be inspected by other processes that happen to be connecting).  - The redis server must be installed. On Linux  this can be installed through apt. It's also available in brew for mac osx.

Title: Ivy to node js
Body: This is a pull request (experimental) that demonstrates the use of a nodejs connecting on a message bus like redis  the ivy-to-redis script. It then listens to "ground._" messages only  which are essentially messages from the server related to aircraft and nicely emitted in a periodic interval. A socket.io client like a browser (with Websockets?) can then connect to the nodejs process and subscribe to the messages for a specific ac_id. All ground._ messages are then transmitted to that client. Multiple clients are possible on multiple aircrafts.  Video demonstrating the concept is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zdg2JiZpUI8&feature=youtu.be  Issues and things to ponder: - I noticed a little bug in the ivy_to_redis script. It forwards data directly from the array  which ends up as ['1' 'xxxx' 'yyy' 'zzz']. So I changed that to convert the array back into a string. Maybe you want to put that in as a separate commit. the file is all the way at the end. - There's a lot of files in this one  but there's a great deal of minimized javascript vs. regular js for debugging. The total size of the update is 1M. I suggest reading from the top until you get to "sw/ground_segment/node/package.json"  which is the main code and install files. Then read back from the bottom until "sw/ground_segment/node/public/js/app.js". That's where the real app code is. The javascript code that performs the main functionality is in controllers.js.  So far  it's only an example  but in the current state quite extendable. A little user interface to select the aircraft you want to track and maybe some buttons to execute some basic functions. GMaps also has the possibility to draw polylines and waypoints. If these are used correctly  any update in the model will immediately reflect in the browser window too. So implementing a UI which shows the flight plan and changes to that is pretty straightforward.

Title: ocaml try to live in harmony with the garbage collector

With this "fix" it looks like memory usage of messages  etc. doesn't increase so drastically anymore. There are probably a few more places where we should do the same (e.g. in ivy-ocaml  see https://github.com/flixr/ivy-ocaml/commit/282d68f750bdeaaf66bfcb9c4aa3270e6c2c65dd)  See http://caml.inria.fr/pub/docs/manual-ocaml/intfc.html#sec440 for the OCaml documentation on this.

Title: Pymath
Body: Usable python wrappers (generated with SWIG) for the Paparazzi algebra and geodetic math lib.  You need to have swig2.0 installed  then to compile:  ``` shell cd $PAPARAZZI_SRC/sw/lib/python/pprz_math make ```  To use the python modules  make sure it is in your PYTHONPATH (or add it to the sys path at runtime of your script). E.g. using it in ipython: `PYTHONPATH=$PAPARAZZI_SRC/sw/lib/python iypthon --pylab`  ``` python from pprz_math.geodetic import * from pprz_math.algebra import FloatEulers  FloatVect3  FloatQuat  FloatRMat  utm_origin = UtmCoor_d(north=377349  east=4824583  alt=147  zone=31) print("origin %s" % utm_origin) lla_origin = utm_origin.to_lla() ecef_origin = lla_origin.to_ecef() ltp_origin = ecef_origin.to_ltp_def() print(ltp_origin)  v = FloatVect3(16 32 64) R = FloatEulers(phi=radians(90)).to_rmat() v2 = FloatVect3(1 2 3) + R * v ```

Title: Improvement of Ivy efficiency
Body: Improving efficiency of Ivy with simpler attached regexp by default (no timestamp)  and by only waiting for ALIVE to detect new plane in 'messages'.  When using timespampped messages (or `-local_timestamp` option of link)  other programs (GCS  server  messages) have to run with the `-timestamp` option.  When messages is used with something else than an autopilot (or anything sending the `ALIVE` message)  but still sending telemetry message  the option `-force` can be used to force waiting on all messages to find new senders.  Tested and working in sim and real link. CPU and network usage slightly improved  even with a single aircraft.

Title: abi allow to pass variables by value

Title: Added send method to python interface and method to get raw data from pp
Body: ...rz message as received on bus;  The ivy bus interface on python didn't have a method to send data over it. This method allows anyone using the interface to (in a direct  crude form) send messages over the bus.  The pprz message class is useful to extract data  but once it's there the order of fields is not guaranteed  so when you want to retransmit it  it may fail  because it returns data by fieldname order rather than fieldvalue order. The fieldvalue order is a list  so it is guaranteed to be in the correct order for retransmission.

Title: AHRS API Interface refactor
Body: Goals: - to allow multiple different AHRS algos running at the same time - no more dependencies on the global imu or ahrs_aligner structs in the ahrs implementation  The idea is that every ahrs has it's own unique names for functions and implementation struct and that you then can e.g. register an ahrs algorithm by passing pointers to to the propagate/update functions.  Question if we also want to support running multiple instances of the same AHRS algorithm in the same process (meaning compiled into same blob)? That would also require to pass the AHRS implementation struct to it's own update functions. But you start to get to a point where you implement C++ features in C  but in a less readable way... -> only one instance per AHRS implementation for now

Title: arch linux sys time thread
Body: Since using SIGALRM to call the sys_tick_handler (via `setitimer`) can cause problems like interrupting some other syscalls (i.e. read write  ioctl)  setup a separate thread and use timer_fd instead. That is a Linux-specific set of functions that presents POSIX timers as file descriptors rather than signals.  If the thread runs with a normal priority it can happen that some timer events are missed (and hence sys_time not updated in time). So added a function to set a higher prio for that thread (needs root rights or properly set up limits for the user). In some simple tests no events were missed when running with prio 29 via SCHED_FIFO  even if events would be missed  the sys_tick_handler is called the appropriate number of times (so that the time is correct again after)...

Title: Refactor AHRS INS with ABI and provide dual AHRS support
Body: Continue refactoring of AHRS and INS: - add GEO_MAG ABI message - add GPS ABI message - remove explicit calling of update_gps functions (replaced by GPS ABI callbacks) - each ins has it's own unique struct/function names - send STATE_FILTER_STATUS from each implementation (with added id if you run multiple ones) - use stateIsAttitudeValid() instead of AHRS.is_aligned   - The state interface is initialized with invalid attitude.     It becomes valid as soon as an attitude is set (via one of the stateSetNedToBodyX functions).     This should be only done by an AHRS/INS after it is aligned. - add possibility to run multiple (currently two) AHRS implementations and switch which one should push the output to the state interface during runtime  `ahrs_init()` and `ins_init()` are now sort of "dispatcher" functions  that init/register the actually used implementation.  As an example using `float_mlkf` as the `PRIMARY_AHRS` and `int_cmpl_quat` as `SECONDARY_AHRS`  in your firmware section of the airframe file:  ```   <subsystem name="ahrs"          type="float_mlkf"/>   <subsystem name="ahrs"          type="int_cmpl_quat">     <configure name="SECONDARY_AHRS" value="int_cmpl_quat"/>   </subsystem> ```  In `ahrs_init()` it calls the ahrs_x_register functions for both. Each of those calls their own ahrs_foo_init and then `ahrs_register_impl(enable_output_function)`  then do the ABI binding and register periodic telemetry functions.  The "enable_output_function" pointer is used to keep a reference to the implementation functions to switch on/off publishing of the output to the state interface. Hence you can call `ahrs_switch(idx)` at runtime to switch the output of the AHRS implementations. E.g. with idx=1 switch to the output of the secondary AHRS (with 0 being the primary) Add the `conf/settings/estimators/ahrs_secondary.xml` settings file to switch them via settings.  Tested on a Lisa/MX 2.0 for those two and seems to work nicely...  TODO: - [x] provide the enable functions for each implementation   - [x] int_cmpl_quat   - [x] float_mlkf   - [x] int_cmpl_euler   - [x] float_cmpl   - [x] float_dcm  Edit: Moved to  #1145 -  ~~implement the same for INS~~ - ~~deal with the remaining "global" ins_reset_x functions (`ins_reset_local_origin`  `ins_reset_altitude_ref`  ...)~~ - ~~get rid of `ins_periodic` for those impls which need it (probably when we start converting them to modules)~~

Title: GPS NMEA parser improvements

Title: Fix GPS furuno Bebop

Since the uart buffer can't hold that many chars  only the first 4 or so config sentences were actually sent. - Added nmea_configure function that is called in GpsEvent until configuration is finished. - updated settings  enabled GSV message

Title: NPS add possibility to simulate loss of datalink downlink

Title: telemetry store periodic telemetry msg names as const to save ram
Body: Make sure that the msg names are stored in rom (.text) and not ram (.data) by making them const. Since the callbacks are not const  replace the telemetry_msg struct by typedef for only the name and separate callback array.  This saves ~ 2.5k of RAM with a standard telemetry file  which is really nice if you try to run Paparazzi on a low end board like the CC3D with only 20k RAM.

Title: navigation implement global waypoints for rotorcraft
Body: - each waypoint is a struct with multiple representations and flags (e.g. if absolute/global) - factor out waypoints in separate files so it can be shared between firmwares later - if a waypoint is defined with lat/lon instead of x/y in the flight plan  it is marked as an absolute/global waypoint and not moved upon GeoInit  Only for rotorcraft so far...

Title: air_data use CAS EAS for airspeed and send TAS in message
Body: On piloted aircraft  the CAS (actually IAS) is used as a flight indication and thus is the controlled airspeed. I suggest to use EAS (very close to CAS for us and easier to compute) for airspeed (the value updating the state interface) and compute TAS (the "real" airspeed) as an extra indication  especially in message instead of tas_factor. One of the reason is that to get a correct TAS you need P  T and P_diff  while EAS/CAS only requires P_diff. Today I flew with an uncalibrated temperature sensor (it was their but not needed) and the result is that my airspeed was completely wrong.  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calibrated_airspeed http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indicated_airspeed http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equivalent_airspeed

Title: vision Opticflow rewrite
Body: Rewrite of the optical flow and vision parts for Linux. This adds a more modular and clean way of adding vision modules and calculations. There is a sample image library which is very well documented and could be expanded in the future.  A lot of improvement to the optical flow calculations could be done  but this is just a simple implementation. In the future we could for example keep track of previous found coners  optimize subpixel calculations etc.  What still needs to be done: - [x] Video device should be changeable - [x] The vision message needs to be periodic - [x] More settings for Lucas Kanade calculation (like window size  amount of iterations etc.) - [x] Camera parameters should be changeable - [x] Check LIBC static linking - [x] Run code style formatter

Title: Flat Theme Icons

The new flat theme hopefully improves readability and adds some new icons related to rotorcraft usage vs. fixed wing.  The new flat theme icons are localized in their own directory named flat_theme in $PAPARAZZI_HOME/data/pictures/gcs_icons. Along with a new set of icons  this directory contains the master GIMP file named flat_theme.xcf.  Reference pull request #1187 for historical background.

Title: Report tool for IMU Scaled messages
Body: A reporting tool to quickly analyze and report scaled IMU data. Useful when building multiple aircraft frames and need to quickly profile vibration benchmarks.  ``` $ ./report_imu_scaled.py -h Usage: report_imu_scaled.py [options] log_filename.data Run report_imu_scaled.py --help to list the options.  Options:   -h  --help            show this help message and exit   -i AC_ID  --id=AC_ID  aircraft id to use   -p  --plot            Show sensor plots   -s START  --start=START                         start time in seconds   -e END  --end=END     end time in seconds   -v  --verbose          ```  Invocation without any options:  ``` ./report_imu_scaled.py ../../paparazzi/var/logs/15_05_30__17_12_41.data  ACCEL : Time Range(26.457 : 168.714)          ax      ay      az Min   [-27.173 -22.560 -94.397] m/s2 Max   [ 28.475  15.217  63.792] m/s2 Mean  [  0.090   0.072  -9.682] m/s2 StDev [ 10.341   4.215  23.733] m/s2  GYRO : Time Range(26.474 : 168.746)          gp      gq      gr Min   [-190.841 -219.992 -114.018] deg/s Max   [176.825 295.725 120.718] deg/s Mean  [ -0.778   0.193   0.043] deg/s StDev [ 50.217  59.724  38.419] deg/s  MAG : Time Range(26.538 : 168.762)          mx      my      mz Min   [ -0.094  -0.564  -0.310] unit Max   [  0.623   0.272   0.981] unit Mean  [  0.270  -0.131   0.279] unit StDev [  0.110   0.115   0.324] unit ```  The -p option produces graphs for each IMU set:  ``` ./report_imu_scaled.py -p ../../paparazzi/var/logs/15_05_30__17_12_41.data ```  ![screen shot 2015-06-02 at 12 21 38 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10355071/7944834/04778970-0922-11e5-9515-60ecf157e119.png) ![screen shot 2015-06-02 at 12 21 57 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10355071/7944838/0b7df574-0922-11e5-8b0c-eb5152980a28.png)  The reporting can also use the -s and -e options to specify the start and end time  respectively of the sample:  ``` ./report_imu_scaled.py -p -s 27 -e 168 ../../paparazzi/var/logs/15_05_30__17_12_41.data ```

Title: modules digital_cam_x specify times in seconds

Changes: - replaces `DC_AUTOSHOOT_QUARTERSEC_PERIOD` with `DC_AUTOSHOOT_PERIOD` (in seconds) - changes `DC_SHUTTER_DELAY` to be in seconds instead of periodic cycles (quarter seconds) - changes `DC_POWER_OFF_DELAY` to be in seconds instead of periodic cycles (quarter seconds) - run dc_periodic at 10Hz instead of 4Hz for more precise shots

Title: conf update udev rules

Title: rotorcraft predefined motor_mixing for common configurations
Body: The intention is to make it easier to configure for common multitrotor configurations.  Motor counting/numbering order is always clockwise  starting with the front motor (for + frame) or left front motor (x frame). This first motor always turns CW  and alternates from there...  Also define `MOTOR_<position>` (e.g. `MOTOR_FRONT_LEFT`) for each motor to be able to use that in the command laws.

Title: rotorcraft heading integration protection in RC event
Body: The PSI += .... was highly depending on the RC-frame rate. With most RC this is not a problem but with variable message rates (e.g. rc_datalink dropping messages or joysticks sending too many frames) this line becomes dangerous.  So measure the time between to calls to read_rc_setpoint function instead of using a fixed RC_UPDATE_FREQ. To prevent really weird things from happening  bound dt to 0.5s.  Don't partuculariliy like that this pulls in the sys_time dependency here  but couldn't think of something better...  should close #452

Title: Dynamic sectors
Body: Allow dynamic sectors (#643)  Currently  it is activated by adding the attribute `type="dynamic"` since it is very experimental code. But it should work with concave hulls.

Title: linux use 8 bit I2C address scheme for all drivers
Body: fixes #1210 needs to be tested as I do not have any Linux target (Bebop  BBB)

Title: rotorcraft try to improve motor mixing priorities
Body: Calculate the amount of yaw authority left after applying roll  pitch and throttle commands. Then limit the yaw command to that.  Simple first shot at improving the priorities in the saturation case  see #385.  Calculating the mean_cmd should not not actually be necessary for symmetric airframes without any trims set. But it shouldn't hurt....  Should (tm) result in zero saturation failures like this  but might severly limit yaw authority. Maybe find some sort of compromise  e.g. use MOTOR_MIXING_MAX_SATURATION_OFFSET when bounding yaw or allow to give less throttle to get more yaw authority....  Not tested in real flight  meant as a basis for discussion/tests...

Title: NPS support gaia environment simulator
Body: Listen to WORLD_ENV message from gaia environment simulator.  So you can use the gaia gui to adjust the wind dir/speed  gps_availability and time factor in the NPS sim. This means you can now also more easily adjust the time factor during runtime (without needing to interrupt NPS with CTRL-Z) Also added a slider for wind up to the gaia gui.

Title: rotorcraft make the heading primitive usable for rotorcrafts
Body: This make the `heading` flight plan primitive usable for rotorcrafts. It has a different behaviour than for fixedwings (where you basically specify a course to fly). For rotorcrafts this sets the heading/yaw.

Title: sdcard direct spi sd card peripheral sd logger module and test driven development framework
Body: The pull request consists of three parts: - An sd-card spi peripheral  for an SD card that is directly wired to a SPI port. It has functions for reading/writing blocks - A logger module that uses the SD card connected to the SPI port. A python application is included which starts/stops/downloads recordings through telemetry messages. - An implementation of a framework for Test Driven Development  using unity and cmock.  The benefit of this is that a small autopilot such as a Lisa/S can be equipped with a light-weight micro-SD card for high speed logging. The micro-SD card can be soldered directly to SPI pins on the autopilot board. We are now able to log IMU data at high speed  for the development of better control loops on small helicopters.  ![sdlogger_download_app_screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8672355/7589136/52446838-f8c1-11e4-9ff6-8ddbdf9d6230.png)  ![sdcard_thumb](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8672355/7589156/6d8b84fa-f8c1-11e4-8c92-4b820d8510ab.jpg)

Title: sdcard new sdcard spi interface
Body: This is a driver for a (micro) SD card connected on the SPI bus. It has functionality for reading and writing raw blocks of data.  See #1179 for previous pull request and discussion.

Title: Mavlink pprzservices
Body: [modules] datalink/mavlink: Added functionality to be able to communicate with a Android-based GCS.   An additional folder called the "mission lib" has also been added and contains the functionality to send and receive calls and changes with respect to the blocks and waypoints defined in the flight plan.

Title: stabilization quat_int IERROR scale fix
Body: This should (tm) result in less of a quantization error for the integral part (less static offset). Reduce the GAIN_PRESCALER_I accordingly so that the gains set in the airframe file keep same scale.  While here also simplify the fb command prescalers/scaling...

Title: Master cleanup of deprecated parts

Title: rename long hobbyking joystick name

Title: Replace NO_RC_THRUST_LIMIT with RC_THRUST_LIMIT
Body: Replace NO_RC_THRUST_LIMIT with RC_THRUST_LIMIT  The fact that default the thrust is limited by rc in autonomous flight is something that has caused a lot of problems for us  because it is very counter intuitive. In my opinion  when I flip the switch to autonomous mode  the drone should be in control  not me.  Typical issues were:  - Why is the drone not climbing?? It is almost crashing!!! oh wait didn't define NO_RC_THRUST_LIMIT - _Put rc_thrust to full in autonomous mode_ Oh no something is going wrong! switch to rc mode  with full thrust -> stabilization fails -> crash  I understand that in some cases it can be useful  so I changed it to a define RC_THRUST_LIMIT  so it can still be defined and used for anyone who explicitly wants to use it.

Title: ins prevent propagation if there are no measurement updates
Body: To prevent the position and velocity estimation from running away while you only have accel measurements (done in the propagation)  Propagate only if we got any measurement during the last INS_MAX_PROPAGATION_STEPS. Otherwise halt the propagation to not diverge and only set the acceleration. This should only be relevant in the startup phase when the baro is not yet initialized and there is no gps fix yet...  Should fix the last remaining part of #1237 in a more generic and robust way.

Title: Optitrack fixes
Body: These are the changes I needed to make  to fly the ARDrone2 in the Cyberzoo  using the optitrack system for altitude and yaw estimation. Without it  several bugs such as #977 appear on quasi-regular basis.  Basically  this disables the baro+magneto (sonar was already disabled) and fixes some code that kind of ignored those settings or caused problems for it.

Title: Add a flag to default motor_mixing types to reverse direction
Body: Define `MOTOR_MIXING_REVERSE` to TRUE to reverse the yaw (motor rotation directions) - flag works on all types - removing X_CCW type

Title: Fixed unsanctioned yaw unkill problem with uninitialised joysticks
Body: Atleast the HobbyKing RC initializes often in such a way that all axis are maxed out. This causes the drone to repeatedly unkill (because of full yaw)  and to dance around violently (because full pitch and roll).   Today I got bitten twice by this problem. Luckily it cost me only 1 finger. This pull request at least prevents the unkill part. (which happens very unexpectedly  just after uploading from center).

Title: gcs don t prove airframe dtd if served via http

This makes it possible to start programs without knowing their absolute path. Already used to start a simple http server from python.  Also parse the args from the programs section of control_panel.xml when starting them from the tools menu. This makes it possible to specify default args.

So we use this instead of killing progs in electrical_init.  Replaces #1251 and is related to #1252

Title: ABI special ID to DISABLE callback
Body: - change ABI_BROADCAST from 0 to 255 - add ABI_DISABLE with id 0 - separate ABI IDs for binding mag message  This makes it easier to explictitly not use an ABI binding by only defining the ID to ABI_DISABLE (zero) without further change of the code. The idea is that you can use it to e.g. disable a mag callback for one AHRS without globally setting USE_MAGNETOMETER to FALSE.   Also make it easy to use a different mag than the one on the IMU. However the mag still has to have the same alignment as the IMU (still same BODY_TO_IMU used).

Title: I2C cleanup error counters and reports

Title: modules addition of simple algorithm for divergence calculation
Body: This branch adds a simple algorithm to determine optical flow divergence to the optical flow code in Paparazzi. It takes the optical flow vectors and evaluates how the distances between corners change over time. This allows to determine the divergence  which is 0 in hover  negative when going up and positive when going down.   The divergence can be used  e.g.  for constant divergence landings  which permit safe landing on surfaces which are not at 0 altitude (roof top for instance).  Main change is the addition of size_divergence.c / h for the calculation of the divergence. The other modifications call the algorithm or pass its values on to the Paparazzi ground station.

Title: rotorcraft linux limit main event loop to 1kHz
Body: This is a kludge until we can better leverage threads and have real events. Without this limit the event flags will constantly polled as fast as possible  resulting on 100% cpu load on boards with an (RT)OS. On bare metal boards this is not an issue  as you have nothing else running anyway.  Enable this for the bebop and ardrone2 by default.  Alternative to #1239 and should fix #1233

Title: multimon fix compilation on gcc 5 x
Body: extern inline has different meaning in gnu11 (C99). We want static inline here  which works in both old and new versions. See also https://gcc.gnu.org/gcc-5/porting_to.html

Title: update natnet to version 2 7
Body: The new version of Motive comes with quite some benefits  so we updated our optitrack system software. That requires these natnet changes to make it work.

Body: Update to the WMM2015 data  Tested in Bebop. More outside testing in different parts of the world welcomed

Title: compile run paparazzi in a docker container
Body: Add docker files and scripts to easily compile and run paparazzi in a Docker container.  cd ~/$PAPARAZZI_HOME/docker `make pull` then you should have the docker images... Run a shell in docker: `make bash` or `make terminator` Then you are in the docker container and you can compile/start paparazzi as usual... If you already compiled paparazzi within docker  you can also directly run paparazzi the next time: `make paparazzi` or `make start`  /dev/ttyx and /dev/ACMx devices are also automatically forwarded to docker and you can flash and use telemetry from within docker.

Title: link try to fix sending LINK_REPORT
Body: this type stuff in OCaml is such a pain...  Fix sending of LINK_REPORT message in link so that server can properly report TELEMETRY_STATUS for each link.  Also actually fill `tx_msgs` and add `datalink_nb_msgs`.  should fix #1278 ~~~ping times still seem to be wrong...~~~

Title: fixing optitrack axes and altitude
Body: With the update the axes were not right anymore. Apparently they have always been a bit oddly defined...  This should fix the axes and the altitude issues

Title: modules viewvideo be nice to other threads
Body: A simple attempt to slightly improve the scheduling  so that taking a shot doesn't block the rest so much.  This sets the computer vision thread nice level to 10  so that the main "thread" should get a little more. It does in no way guarantee that something in the cv thread (like taking a pic) will not block the main functions like estimation  stabilization.  A better long term solution would probably be to run both the main program/thread and this module with the FIFO scheduler and give the cv thread a really low prio.  Not tested due to lack of hardware right now...  Making a pull request to ease testing  documentation and discussion about this...

Title: Rename uart udp_transmit to uart udp_put_byte
Body: Since these functions only add one byte to the tx buffer but don't necessarily already send that byte  rename them to better reflect the functionality.

Title: more optitrack flight plan improvements
Body: Correct waypoints  kill on land  etc.

Title: improvement standard Optitrack flightplan
Body: A few settings in the standard optitrack flight plan were annoying me  like the altitude at 5 meters (and the whole 150m offset thing).

Title: GPS Nmea parser fixes
Body: Make the crappy NMEA parser a little bit less crappy...  CRC of the incoming messages is still not checked...

Title: Message gps lla with hmsl
Body: In an attempt to reduce confusion and make debugging easier  add hmsl to the GPS_LLA message.

Title: settings add optional target attribute to settings
Body: If not target attribute is given  the settings are added for all targets like before.  This makes it easier to add settings files to the conf that are only valid for some targets like nps or some that you don't want when using the test progs.  Beware of: if you compile a target that unloads some settings or modules (e.g. the sim) after you uploaded to the ap  the `var/aircrafts/<ac>/settings.xml` file that has all usable settings combined will change ~~~and the hence the wrong ones used in GCS and settings prog~~~.  Now the calculation of the MD5sum is taking unloaded settings into account  meaning it will change and warn the user if the last compiled target has different settings.

Title: linux replace mcu event polling with threads
Body: On the linux arch  instead of polling for data to read/write in the uart and udp event functions  start a thread that handles incoming data.  This should make it possible to limit the main event loop to 1kHz as per #1240.  uart_transmit should always be able to directly write the single byte to the serial device  and hence no need to use the tx queue. Since the uart threads calls select on the fds to check when there is something to read  it will not wake up if there is data in the tx buffer...  Using the tx buffer was previously done because the system timer was generating signals and interrupted the write. Since this is no longer the case it should be fine like this (unless someone adds something that will interrupt the writes again).  Seems to work fine on the bebop and beagle bone black.

Title: uncomment prerr_endline stuff
Flight Gear visualisation with native fdm
Body: Allows using NPS with Flight Gear's Native FDM. As a result  it is possible to show moving control surfaces (flaps  ailerons etc) and spinning propeller.   Simulator has to be started with `--fg_fdm 1` option  and flight gear with `--native-fdm` option (instead of `--native_gui`).   For example NPS launch command: `./sw/simulator/pprzsim-launch -a Bixler -t nps --js_dev 0 --fg_host 127.0.01 --fg_fdm 1`  And Flight Gear launch command: `fgfs --fdm=null --native-gui=socket in 30  5501 udp --prop:/sim/model/path=Models/Aircraft/paparazzi/easystar.xml`  More about Native FDM for Flight Gear here: http://wiki.flightgear.org/index.php/Property_Tree/Sockets

Title: nps Added example with fixedwing
Body: Added NPS target for Bixler as an example

Title: arch linux uart fix crash if device is wrong
Body: if the serial port can't be openend (e.g. because the device is wrong/doesn't exist)  set the reg_addr to NULL and properly check that everywhere  should close #1296

Title: Transparent subsystems
Body: Add transparent ("dummy") subsystems  so we can compile the airframe even without a specific subsystem (imu  ahrs   gps). Useful when one subsystem takes the function of multiple subsystems.  An example is an external INS sensor - such as MTI-G or Vectornav. Using such an INS we dont need GPS  IMU and AHRS subsystems  but we still have to include them so the AP code compiles properly.   Or if we are using GX3 (and AHRS module)  we dont need IMU subsystem and so on.

Title: ground segment Added geometry param to messages and settings agents
Body: You can now provide for example `-g 300x400-0-200` to settings and messages agents to set the position and size of the window on launch. Useful if you want to recreate a session exactly. Useful for sessions with a lot of windows like the Raw Sensors and Scaled Sensor sessions.

Title: pprz center Added Raw and Scaled sensor session examples
Body: These sessions open real time plotters with curves and constants prepopulated. Also it locates the windows more or less nicely on the screen.  When we add positioning parameter to messages and settings we could put those windows in predefined places too.  After starting one of the two sessions you only have to switch to the correct message set using the settings app. And you should :tm: be good to go! :smile_cat:

Title: PPRZ Center Add AIRCRAFT placeholder constant
Body: When you use @AIRCRAFT as a constant parameter to a program in your session  it will be automatically replaced by the name selected in the A/C dropdown combo box of the Paparazzi Center. This makes it possible to create generic sessions that start programs which need to know which aircraft is of interest. For example settings.  This is a possible solution to the #1215 issue.  [edit] Changed the comment here to reflect the final patch  decrease confusion.

Title: ocaml Fixed compilation of the sim target on OS X
Body: Sim target could not find the lib-pprz.cma.

Title: Setup Actuators Fix telemetry and add more boards
Body: The firmware was crashing because the transport was not being initialized. Added example airframe files for Lisa/MX V2.0 and V2.1. As well as appropriate example sessions.

Title: stm32f4_spektrum Fixes the additional glitch pulse
Body: If you set the alternate function before setting the pin to input AF. The GPIO will pull down the line down very briefly. This will cause an additional pulse to be detected by a spektrum satellite if it is being reconfigured as a UART RX after sending bind mode pulses.  This was tested on Lisa/MX 2.1. It is unlikely but might cause issues for other STM32F4 autopilots. This is why I am sending this in as a pull request instead of pushing the patch directly.

Title: Lisa M Lisa MX Added IMU subsystems for V2 1
Body: The Lisa/M and Lisa/MX V2.1 have an integrated Aspirin like IMU. The orientation of the sensors is bit different than the Aspirin so for backwards compatibility we need to assign the axis appropriately. To do that we add IMU subsystem makefiles and one additianal raw sensor data field assignement.

Title: Spektrum Configure the bind pin to be pullup pulldown
Body: All Lisa/M and Lisa/MX prior to V2.1 don't have a dedicated pull resistor on the bind pin. We were configuring the pin as floating input. This will result in random behaviour  depending on the charge of the GPIO. The system will decide to set the satellites into bind mode depending on how much moist finger is present on the pin. We want something more decisive than that. :)

Title: Lisa_M X 21
Body: This two patches add support for Lisa/MX V2.1 and Lisa/M V2.1 respectively.  The only major difference that is reflected in software is the fact that we now have a dedicated bind button and are not abusing the ADC1 pin for that purpose any more.

Title: NPS Fixed NPS compilaton on OS X
Body: OS X uses clang to compile the code  thus we have a bit different warning system. Now the C++ code is being compiled with the G++ clang compiler instead of GCC. Also fixed some other warnings including UTF-16 character usage.

Title: Lisa S V1 0 support
Body: Let's try it again. :)  I renamed all (hopefully) Lisa/S files to V1.0. All the V1.0 files should work with no problems on the V0.1 hardware. This change should make our life easier in the future  as well as mitigate confusion on the users end. :)  Added the option to change the base tick clock of the servo pwm driver. This makes it possible to use the driver to directly PWM control a brushed motor. See comment on the respective commit for details.  Also added an airframe file that should work with Lisa/S on LadyBird brushed motor nano quadcopter frame. I have tested it on my ladybirds.  No testing has been done on altitude hold and position hold yet. These sections of the airframe file might need some additional improvement in the future. I just copied those sections from TU-Delft airframe that they used/tested on IMAV2013 using a similar nano quadcopter and Lisa/S V0.1.

Title: Lisa S V1 0 support
Body: - Adding Lisa/S V1.0 board files. - Fixed SuperbitRF telemetry - Added airframe file for Lisa/S V1.0 on a LadyBird brushed motor airframe.

Title: Paparazzi Center on Mac OS X fix
Body: This patch fixes issiue #290  The missing HUP signal was found in the simulated poll function in glib. The glib implementation is copied from glibc which does not implement HUP but only generates an IN event instead (Mac OS default behavior would be to generate HUP & IN events together). The solution I went for was to just check if the channel is empty on IN event  and call the HUP callback.  Overall the whole implementation in the pc_common.ml is bit kludgy and would be nice to streamline/clean up  but I rather change as little as possible for now to not introduce unexpected regressions while fixing this. :)  I tested the fix on current Ubuntu as well as Mavericks  and it "works for me"(TM)

Title: GCS label outlines
Body: This adds outlines to the text labels on the 2d map. This solution is inspired by the subtitles in movies where one has a dark outline of a light text or the other way around to make sure that independent of the background the text will always be readable.

Title: Locm3 stylefix update
Body: locm3 went through a stylefix round. Due to that it is not defining the old linux kernel style int types (u8  u16  u32) These patches remove the use of those types from paparazzi as we mostly use the stdint types anyways. No need to be inconsistent. This also updates luftboot to a version that is not relying on those types either.

Title: stabilization yaw damper and active lift ctrl
Body: something up for testing (it already passed some real world test flying) - adaptive ctrl also for pitch - a yaw damper with full turn compensation - active trim of by for straight aerodynamic flights - active lift control for those with four flaps on the wing  the yaw damper is for fixed wings with small stability problems in the yaw axis or for every one else who just don t want to guess anymore about this line     set servo="RUDDER" value="@YAW + @ROLL*COMBI_SWITCH"/> just change it to      set servo="RUDDER" value="@YAW"/> and the yaw damper will take care of the rest I did some testing with two different planes and it looks much better than without but anyone is invited to share is experience!  the active lift loop was only meant to be an idea but I already  filled in quiet a part... so far I only did bench testing since I haven't a plane with four flap configuration - should work never the less.   if some one wants to test please setup you airframe file for the servos and H_CTL section like this:  ``` <set servo="RUDDER" value="@YAW"/> <set servo="FLAP" value="@CL"/> <define name="YAW_LOOP" value="TRUE"/>  <define name="YAW_TRIM_BY" value="TRUE"/> <define name="YAW_DGAIN" value="5000."/> <define name="YAW_BY_IGAIN" value="500."/> <define name="CL_LOOP" value="TRUE"/> <define name="CL_LOOP_USE_AIRSPEED_SETPOINT" value="TRUE"/> <!--default uses IAS--> <define name="CL_FLAPS_STALL" value="0.66"/> <define name="CL_FLAPS_NOMINAL" value="0."/> <define name="CL_FLAPS_RACE" value="-0.2"/> <define name="CL_DEADBAND" value="0."/> ```

INS Vectornav VN 200 driver
Body: - Allows user to use Vectornav VN-200 as an external IMU for either fixedwing or rotorctraft. - No other subsystems (IMU  AHRS  GPS) are needed  all is self-contained - Compatible with NPS  so the airframe with Vectornav can be compiled for both AP and NPS targets  **Note:** Part of the pull request is re-addition of float IMU  since we are getting all data from Vectornav as float  so it makes sense to keep it that way.

Title: Implemented MILLIAMP_AT_IDLE_THROTTLE in current estimation
Body: This change allows to define MILLIAMP_AT_ZERO_THROTTLE  which is the current estimation when the motors are running  but zero throttle is applied (this is relevant for rotorcrafts). This makes it possible to calibrate for a change in the magnetic field caused by starting the motors.  By default  MILLIAMP_AT_ZERO_THROTTLE is set to 0  so there is no change needed for existing airframe configurations.  Additionally  the range of x  which represents the throttle command  is now limited to [0  1] in both directions to prevent math errors.

Title: INDI simplified stabilization for rotorcrafts
Body: This is a slightly simplified version of the Incremental Nonlinear Dynamic Inversion (INDI) controller I made for quadrotor attitude control. I tried to condense it to a form where it can be useful and understandable for others.  I submitted a paper to the journal of guidance  control and dynamics which covers all the details. In short: By measuring the angular acceleration (which is obtained by deriving and filtering it from the gyroscope) we can measure how much the actual angular acceleration differs from the desired angular acceleration. By multiplying this with the inverse of the actuator effectiveness we get the correct increment of the input that will result in the desired increment in angular acceleration. The main benefit is that disturbances can be rapidly compensated and nonlinear dynamics are controlled better.  It also contains an adaptive algorithm  that will update the actuator effectiveness in flight. You can take off with a drone without knowing the actuator effectiveness and it will learn this during the flight  removing the need for tuning. The only thing you need is a constant for the first order approximation of the motor dynamics. This can be measured with a step response  and a value for the ARDrone is included. I will upload more airframes later.  I hope it will be easy to apply to other airframes  but it is hard to guarantee that the adaptive least mean squares algorithm will converge to the right values  because it depends on the amount of filtering and the adaptation rate (these are linked). In general: if the airframe is well-damped it will work better.  In the airframe file I kept the normal attitude stabilization section  to be able to switch easily. A small problem is that the setpoint defines need the prefix STABILIZATION_ATTITUDE   so they are taken from the STABILIZATION_ATTITUDE section instead of the STABILIZATION_INDI section. I wasn't sure how to get around this.

datalink New serial message interface for python
Body: This library can send and receive paparazzi messages over a serial data link  without using Ivy.  Subscribe to messages with the subscribe function. The callback gets a SerialMessage as argument  which will have the requested data in payload_items. Example: `subscribe("DL_VALUE"  myCallbackFunction)`  Send messages using the sendMessage function. Example: `sendMessage("datalink"  "SETTING"  (setting_id  aircraft_id  setting_value))`  Takes control of the serial link so it cannot be used simultaneously with the GCS for example.

This is mainly a cludge for entry level radios with no three-way switch  but two available two-way switches which can be used.

Title: Chibios update to 2 6 9
Body: Update ChibiOS to 2.6.9 version  contains some bugfixes and cleanups.  Had to remove the -Werror flag  because the ChibiOS USB driver implementation is missing a return statement in a thread which never terminates:  ``` paparazzi/sw/ext/chibios/os/hal/platforms/STM32/OTGv1/usb_lld.c: In function 'usb_lld_pump': paparazzi/sw/ext/chibios/os/hal/platforms/STM32/OTGv1/usb_lld.c:769:1: error: no return statement in function returning non-void [-Werror=return-type] cc1: all warnings being treated as errors ```  It is not great to have errors like this  but in this case it seems to be fine. Possible solution is to ask for a fix at ChibiOS forum.

Title: datalink Extended bluegiga spi message to 20 bytes
Body: I finally identified and fixed the error of the missing first byte in the spi message. The dma buffer copies the first byte of the tx buffer into the spi peripheral immediately when the register for slave transaction command is called  that was not immediately clear. I added a comment to the spi_arch to reflect this fact.  After fixing this I found another small "feature" in the send_message function in bluegiga which improves the responsiveness of the tx flow.  I also added code for transactions with the spi3 slave peripheral  compiles but not tested.  I removed the software slave management code. As was implemented if spi2 slave management was set to software all spi slaves would also use software management...  Last and not least I added the firmware needed to run onboard the bluegiga module.

Title: Mavlink additions
Body: Add extra functionality of #1407 to current mavlink module. - fix sending of some mavliink messages (MAVLinkSendMessage() was missing) - send GPS_STATUS and VFR_HUD   - and actually fill in more fields - parse MISSION_ITEM message to update waypoints   - only for rotorcraft (since it used the waypoint interface  see https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/issues/981)   - actually take the frame into account - add the Paparazzi specific SCRIPT_ITEM messages  Looks to me like this now added the same functionality as #1407 with two minor differences: - ~~no time-outs on the mission or script protocol  don't see how they would be relevant anyway since you can only change existing waypoints/blocks~~ - ~~MISSION_ITEM message is sending waypoint in `MAV_FRAME_LOCAL_ENU` instead of `MAV_FRAME_GLOBAL`~~ only for fixedwing   - this has the advantage of having higher precision (representing lat/lon in float is not nice)   - still works correctly with the android app?  This should keep all the already existing functionality that #1407 doesn't have: - works for UART  UDP  USB serial - more messages supported - support of changing settings - override RC channels - support rotorcraft and fixedwing (except for waypoint changes) - more accurately report current mode  type  etc...  One thing I was wondering about: why add a len field to the SCRIPT_ITEM message? It seems to be totally superfluous to me...  @dewagter @LodewijkSikkel what do you guys think? And plz test with your setup...

Title: sd logger Version 2 0 release direct SPI logging UART download
Body: This module provides a tool for high-speed logging where weight- and size-limitations play part. It only requires a micro-SD card which is soldered directly to the SPI-bus  for example on a lisa/s.  The logger is activated by flipping a switch on the transmitter. Up to 42 logs can be recorded during one session (battery kept connected). The data remains on the card when the battery is disconnected  so that you can replace the battery before downloading data to the computer. Previous logs will be overwritten as soon as the first log is initiated after boot.  The messages to be logged can be selected in the telemetry config file  under the Logger process. Next to that  it is possible to call pprz_msg_send_xxx from anywhere in the code  using a reference to the sdlogger.   Telemetry config example:  ``` <process name="Logger">   <mode name="default">     <message name="ROTORCRAFT_STATUS"      period="1.2"/>     <message name="DL_VALUE"               period="0.5"/>     <message name="ALIVE"                  period="2.1"/>     <message name="IMU_GYRO_SCALED"        period=".002"/>     <message name="IMU_ACCEL_SCALED"       period=".002"/>     <message name="IMU_MAG_SCALED"         period=".1"/>   </mode> </process> ```  A tool is provided to download the data at high speed over UART: ![screenshot from 2015-10-27 14 27 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8672355/10759307/eb0115fc-7cb6-11e5-8cd9-5c8f18a2d79b.png) ![screenshot from 2015-10-27 14 27 51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8672355/10759308/ecfdcc38-7cb6-11e5-822c-0d6277cfcc78.png)  Limitations: For now  it can only be used with uart downlink. This is perfect for lisa/s where UART pins are broken out.

Title: Register multiple periodic messages
Body: So far when multiple modules/subsystem were calling `register_periodic_telemetry` for the same message/string  only the first one would actually register it's callback.  For cases like #1145 we would like to register multiple callbacks  so: - Allow to add multiple callbacks: up to `TELEMETRY_NB_CBS` slots (4 right now). - Also return slot index of callback (to make it easier to add an `unregister` function later) or -1 on failure

Title: Add component filter ID to AHRS messages
Body: When running multiple AHRS algos in parallel  each filters can send the same message but with a different ID to distinguish the source. See also #1145   This adds a `comp_id` field to the following messages: - AHRS_EULER - AHRS_EULER_INT - AHRS_QUAT_INT - AHRS_RMAT_INT - AHRS_GYRO_BIAS_INT - GEO_MAG  Also register some more message in some of the filters and don't use the value from the state interface to send the attitude in body frame but rather compute it from the actual ahrs output (imu frame). So it will still be correct if muliple AHRS are running and another one is enabled (sets the attitude in the state interface).

And probably more importantly  these constant updates of the menu result in high cpu-load and memory usage of hud-service  Rendering the computer unusable if left running for a long time (until hud-service is killed and restarted).  Workaround for #1446 by simply disabling the update of these labels/menu entries

Title: Change register_periodic_telemetry to use defines instead of string for matching
Body: So far `register_periodic_telemetry` takes a string as argument and compares it to the strings in used telelemetry xml files to register the callback. This makes it possible to have "meta" names for messages  meaning that name does not need to correspond to an actual message. E.g. if you would register "MYMODULE" and have a "MYMODULE" as message name in the telemetry.xml file  the callback would be registered and you could send any message from within that.  However this requires the strings to be stored in ROM (flash) for comparison...  On small systems (e.g. CC3D  naze32  etc) with very small flash this becomes a major limitation. The proposal here is to drop the "meta" name functionality and instead require to use an actual message name (actually a generated define)  so it can be reduced to a simple numerical id.  So the main question is if we want to sacrifice the flexibility we currently have to reduce ROM size on the very small systems?

Title: spi SPI slave implemented and tested for STM32F4
Body: This expands the spi slave protocol to include the stm32F4. This was tested with a bluegiga bluetooth module and a Discovery board to verify its operation. A couple of comments:  The spi slave works really well with spi3  this was fully tested and verified. For some reason when using spi1  after about 1 second paparazzi stops sending data over the datalink although the spi continues to run(I verified this by sending an incrementing value everytime the spi dma returned)  no idea why this is. Although I could clearly see the spi still working I can't say for certain that this works totally for spi1. In my test using spi2 the MISO pin remained low the entire time and didn't work for me  again not sure why  it uses exactly the same code as the other two so...  I added warnings to each spi reflecting the level of testing done thus far.  This will not work out of the box with the discovery board as the spi slave defines in the discovery board are not the alternate function NSS pins as defined by STM. These are true for the LisaM and Lisa MX so this will work for them. I am not sure why the pin definitions are different for these boards. If you like I can push the alternate function definitions as defined by STM. Let me know.  The bluegiga protocol is changed slightly.  The updated spi code still works with the F1 as tested with a lisa/s with bluegiga.  Let me know what you think.

Title: Change register_periodic_telemetry to use msg ID and support other protocols mavlink
Body: Alternative to #1442: - Change register_periodic_telemetry() to use msg ID - possibility to use register_periodic_telemetry for mavlink and others.   -  in the telemetry xml file a type can be specified for the process (default is "pprz").   - You can also set "mavlink" and use mavlink messages  which will be sent as specified if the mavlink module is loaded and that mavlink message is registered there. - use PPRZ_MSG_ID_x instead of DL_x  This requires an extra unit8_t id field in the struct (so if you have 20 different messages in the telmetry file  this would add an extra 20bytes compared to #1442). At runtime it will loop over the periodic messages until it finds the matching id (compared to already knowing the index). Also this really makes it impossible to register "meta/alias" messages... but I would argue that even in #1442 this is not nice since you need to provide the #ifndefs in the code...
