My opinion is that before is better: it will let users (both people using stable and dev branches) to prepare their airframes to the new format that may become the standard in later versions.

Title: default 0 for gravity heuristic
Body: This is a solution for state estimation for rotorcraft that suffer from intense vibrations. We have and had frames that vibrate a lot and always had really bad state estimation on these vehicles. @bartslinger suggested it might be because of the gravity heuristic  and it indeed makes a world of difference.   This makes sense  because when there are large vibrations on the accelerometer  the norm will be larger or smaller than zero most of the time. Effectively  the accelerometer is then used a lot less (and randomly more or less at one instant compared to the next sample).  I validated this hypothesis in Matlab by taking the ahrs algorithm with and without gravity heuristic. The difference is very large (on a vibrating platform).  I am not sure how much good this thing is doing compared to the downside I mention above. One possibility is to have the default to be 0. Alternatively  if people really like the heuristic I can also change it in my airframe files.

Title: Simplified rate control

Title: Avoiding conditional directives that split up parts of statements

Title: Multigps Subsystem
Body: Out of the necessity of robustness from the Piksi RTK gps system I've written this subsystem which automatically switches between two gps units. Its completely compatible as a gps subsystem so all one needs to do to use it is set: `<subsystem name="gps"  type="multi"/>`  I've added GCS strip settings to manually select between the two gps's if you just add settings/rotorcraft_basic_multi.xml. New messages MULTI_GPS_INT_PRIMARY and MULTI_GPS_INT_SECONDARY report the status of individual GPS units and PIKSI_HEARTBEAT reports the heartbeat for the piksi (since piksi wont send any kind of position messages without lock).  The subsystem switches when the fix of one gps is higher than that of the other.   There is currently only support for one Piksi and one Ublox gps.

Title: direct NED to ENU for N and E
Body: I noticed that waypoints I enter in NED do not exactly result in exactly those coordinates in the generated flight plan. In the generated flight plan  my NED waypoint {-2.0  0.0  1.6} goes to {-2.00  0.04  1.60}  / ENU in meters / . The ENU waypoint is what is used in the navigation.  This seems kind of silly to me  as it should be really simple to go from NED to ENU. The transformation happens in the flight plan generator in the function print_waypoint_enu. In this function the waypoints are first converted to ECEF and then to NED. This is where I think the error is introduced. I suppose this is to get the correct altitude if you use alt or height. But there is no reason to use the east and north values from NED->ECEF->ENU.

Examples for targets WITHOUT unaligned access support: LPC21xx  Cortex-M0 - will help air-to-air communications (#1509)  Should be a cleaner implementation of #1527

Title: Multigps Integrated
Body: Added some changes from #1455. Gone is the gps_multi subsystem. Still set with subsystem="gps" type="multi". Now integrated with gps.c/gps.h. Currently  the only supported units are one piksi with one ublox but its still compatible with other implementations of (single) gps's. To add multigps support to a gps unit just change GPS_LINK  add a GpsState and GpsTimeSync to that device and add the proper callback registrations. It's important to note that when using multigps or ublox or piksi  GPS_TYPE_H is undefined and in its place is PRIMARY_GPS_TYPE_H. This is important for compatibility with the other GPS's not addressed in this PR.

Title: support for multiple GPS
Body: This is a cleaned up and finished version of #1511   To e.g. use piksi as a secondary GPS:  ``` <subsystem name="gps" type="ubx">   <configure name="UBX_GPS_PORT" value="UART2"/> </subsystem> <subsystem name="gps" type="piksi">   <configure name="PIKSI_GPS_PORT" value="UART3"/>   <configure name="SECONDARY_GPS" value="piksi"/> </subsystem> ```  Each GPS implementation has their own `GpsState` struct now. We still have the global `gps` struct for now (which gets set to the currently best GPS)  but the goal is to get rid of that global struct later as well...

Title: Fixed and tested magnetometer

All is now fine  note that this is a fix for regular Bebop  and has nothing to do with Bebop2  Bebop2 is another **product ** not another version. Raw values monitored  scaled compared etc. etc.  Yes  it is only one - (minus) sign difference that make all the difference from non- autonomous flight to OK autonomous flight.

Title: Gcs icon themes
Body: Add a new set of icons for use with the GCS. The current classic icons are sometimes difficult to see against a black GCS screen(i.e. papgets). The new `flat theme` hopefully improves readability and adds some new icons related to rotorcraft usage vs. fixed wing. Another goal was to introduce new icons without impacting existing users flight plan icon paths and their use of existing `classic` icons.  The new flat theme icons are localized in their own directory named `flat_theme` in `$PAPARAZZI_HOME/data/pictures/gcs_icons`. Along with a new set of icons  this directory contains the master GIMP file named `flat_theme.xcf`.  In addition to the new `flat_theme` directory  the existing set of icons are mirrored in a `classic_theme` directory under  the `$PAPARAZZI_HOME/data/pictures/gcs_icons` directory. By mirroring the data  it provides a migration path from the existing monolithic icon name space to a theme based naming model. So for completeness  a `classic_theme` directory was needed.  Currently  the GCS derives it's icons location from the `gcs_icons_path` variable set in  `$PAPARAZZI_HOME/sw/lib/ocaml/env.ml`  ``` let gcs_icons_path = paparazzi_home // "data" // "pictures" // "gcs_icons" ```  Eventually  the `gcs_icons_path` could be overlayed via the aircraft configuration xml file or other template. Whatever the solution for setting the `gcs_icon_path`  it might be good to have an approach that allows for custom icons at the individual aircraft level.   The approach/solution for setting a theme is open for discussion. There are multiple approaches for solving this issue. In the mean time  by encapsulating theme based icons in their own directories  simple file overlaying techniques can be used to get new icon behaviors.  Note that flight plans and GCS layout files have dependencies on the `gcs_icons_path`. The `strip_icon` attribute in flight plans and the `icon` property in GCS layout files assume icon files are rooted at the location defined by `gcs_icons_path`. Minimizing negative impacts to existing user's flight plans and GCS layout files is important. Hopefully  it would be "transparent".  This is an image of the new "flat_theme" used for strip buttons and as papgets. ![screen shot 2015-05-18 at 10 47 02 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10355071/7807081/2ef04646-033d-11e5-9251-cf5807450746.png)

Title: Pixhawk flies with intermcu on Iris
Body: First PR for getting Pixhawk to play nice with PPRZ.   The Pixhawk can be flashed without external tools (i.e. no JTAG interface is needed). Instead  the PX4 bootloader is kept in place and used by pprz to flash both the AP (stm32f4) and FBW (stm32f1) devices. One important remark is that for the FBW device  currently the computer needs to be connected to the Telem2 port using a FTDI cable. This is because pprz does not support serial communication over USB  or so I've heard.  In any case  the Iris+ drone factory equipped with a Pixhawk flies both on INDI and PID in ATT mode. However  PPRZ currently uses the MPU6000 IMU  which was broken in my Iris+ (and there are indications that maybe in others Iris' and X8's as well). I had to replace it with a fresh Pixhawk.  Also tested with a Pixhawk clone: seems to work just as well.  There are some things on the todo list: 1. Enable USB2serial communication :) 2. Led 3 (which is a led embedded in a separate push button to be mounted somewhere on the air-frame) is used to signal the FBW status. Should be made generic (either by a module  or by a LED def or something) 3. The 1500000 baud rate is necessary to remain compatible with flashing back to original PX4 firmware  however the communication has shown some stability issues. Strange  because original PX4 also uses this baud... The 24MHz external crystal used with the f1 is however outside the specs  so it may have something to do with that. 4. Drivers are missing for:      The spi L3GD20H gyro       The multi color led 5. Only ATT mode has been tested. Autonomous flight using  GPS  baro and magneto has not been done or tested.  Specific to the Iris: 6. Enable the Gimbal controll through the RC

Title: edgeflow improved optic flow calculation
Body: Hi   I developed a new method to calculate the global optical flow in a efficient way. It should run twice as fast as the current implementation.  I tried to rewrite the opticflow_calculator.c a bit so that more methods can be added more easily  since before it was specifically written for fast9/LK implementation. On top of that I tried to use the existing structures as much as possible  so that I can switch between different methods on the fly. A couple of new files are added to the lib folder (edge_flow.c & .h)  Any comments/ suggestions for changes are welcome. @dewagter  can you also take a look at this?   Cheers  K

I have adapted the fixed-wing implementation and ported to rotorcraft as well. Unlike fixed-wing  the rotorcraft implementation uses binary fixed-point representation rather than floats.

Title: PX4 motor random spin up issues
Body: Turned out that having 1500000 baud between the f1 and f4 on the Pixhawk board was rather heisenbuggy. After some time (ca half an hour stationary  but with power from battery) packages started getting lost.   To remain backwards compatible with PX4 firmware  the 150000 baud is still required. However  during flight not. So the baud rate is set to 230400 after 10 seconds.  This PR -fixes the above baud issue   -adds some signalling information to the FBW LED  -fixes some issues related to FBW_MANUAL_MODE   which caused the motors to spin up shortly during intermcu loss.

Title: pprzlink update for new API of pprzlink using fd parameter
Body: See https://github.com/paparazzi/pprzlink/pull/5  This update in the pprzlink API allow to pass a parameter (long int) to the transport and device function. It can be an address  a file descriptor  an index ... This will allow a more efficient sending of messages especially when using transaction queues or malloc and for the ongoing chibios implementation.

Created a PX4 imu  which consists out of     a) lsm303dlhc (acc) + l3g (gyro) IMU  both on spi    b) the MPU6050 (acc + gyro) IMU  on spi.    c) 2 magneto's: one in the lsm303dlhc and an external i2c hmc5811 in the 3dr gps 3. Changed the ms5611 baro to spi  (this PR builds on #1566  which was not merged yet)

Title: remove scaling from rate feedback
Body: Currently gains from rate control do not carry over to attitude stabilization  because there is a factor 2 in the rate control and prescaler values (factor 3 for rate) in the attitude control. I searched through the airframes  and there are not many that use rate control. I doubled all the gains and removed rate control for bebop  as rate control over datalink is very difficult due to lag.  The prescaler values should also be default 1 for stabilization quat_int  as they already are for float_quat. However  this will mean updating a large amount of airframes  which will require some scripting. I might have time for this later.

Title: Added optical flow landing module
Body: I added an optical flow landing module. It uses the size divergence from the optical flow algorithm to keep a constant divergence (if set negative the drone will land  0 = hover  and positive is going up). Advantage with respect to a GPS landing is that it will take into account the landing surface  even if it is higher than the ground level (so landing on a roof for instance). The module does not use sonar for the vertical control  so it can be used by tiny drones that do not carry sonar. The module uses a novel theory on seeing distances with just a single camera (no extra sensors) to detect when it should land. So it can also be used by drones to estimate distance with a single camera.

Title: converted PI rate controller to floating point

Anyway  the idea being that you can easily calculate the command after 1 sec 1 rad/s error with the current I gain  for instance compared to the P gain. Now I think about it... maybe dividing by periodic frequency is even better...   On a side note  the messages are now also in float  so do I have to make a pull request to pprzlink as well? Why is this separate by the way?

Title: The udev rules were not detecting Lisa M V2 1 correctly

Previous versions of Lisa/M DFU bootloader did not have the hardware version in them. This is needed so that the Lisa/M DFU is accessible from the userspace in the plugdev group.

Title: First attempt for geofencing
Body: Hi folks  this is related to #1616 - and is my first attempt for more "professional" / "industrial" geofencing feature.  What it does? 1) instead of HOME and MAX_DIST_FROM_HOME the user has to define FlightArea (convex polygon) 2) there is now a compulsory MAX_ALTITUDE attribute in the flight plan 3) if the plane is out of flight area or higher than max altitude  it goes to STANDBY mode 4) STANDBY mode is essentially a modified HOME mode - except instead of going to HOME it goes to STANDBY waypoint (name negotioable) 5) STANDBY waypoint cannot be moved 6) we want to check that STANDBY is defined inside flight area 7) there is also INIT mode of the autopilot  which is triggered upon startup - basically it tells you a reset happened  otherwise it is equivalent to AUTO2/NAV mode locked to circle around STANDBY waypoint. 8) If datalink is lost for more than 30s the plane goes to HOME/STANDBY mode (replaces an optional exception) 9) eventually kills the plane if more than 500 meters outside the flight area (until then try to steer it back)  I made small modifications in the OCaml code  but more guidance here is welcome (especially about how to check if a waypoint is inside flight area). This is more to support a use case for lets say industrial/professional users of pprz  who need better safety than max_dist_from_home circle.  let me know what you think.  Thanks.

Title: Rename values to cmd_values
Body: `values` in the `command_laws` section is renamed to `cmd_values`. This is done in order to be able to use `radio_control.values` inside `command_laws`. Replace command is: `find conf/airframes -type f -print0 | xargs -0 sed -i 's/ values/ cmd_values/g'`

Body: I.e. sometimes we dont want the half width turn at the end of the survey (because we want consistent spacing between images).   Also the poly survey now can be run multiple times  you just have to reset the counter in GCS.

Title: modules Add OPA controller
Body: Special controller for the OPA (Oversized paparazzi Autopilot)  which enables the full functionally of the the board. This includes: - Power of AP from FBW - Power of Motor from FBW - Power of Charging of FBW battery from FBW - Disabling power of Motor from AP settings trough FBW - Power of Vision computer trough AP

Title: Launcher takeoff routine

Title: Skid landing
Body: Added skid landing routine. It is similar to the landing blocks in the flight plans  but it is a single routine so it is easier to use. Meant for fixedwings that land on their belly  see video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aYrB7s3oeX4  Includes improved flare handling  which makes the last section of the landing much smoother.

Title: modules add ins_skeleton
Body: INS module skeleton. This module is meant to be used with an additional module which implements any of the following - ins_module_init() - ins_module_propagate(struct Int32Vect3 *accel  float dt) - ins_module_update_gps(struct GpsState *gps_s  float dt) - ins_module_update_baro(float pressure) - ins_module_reset_local_origin(void)  In each of those functions the updated estimate has to be written to the ins_module struct  which is then used to update the state interface.  alternative proposal to #1572

Title: statefilter in a module pull request
Body: If someone is implementing a new  non-standard statefilter  e.g. in order to test a new filter approach or just for research  it would be both handy and favourable to do so within a module rather than directly in `subsystems/ins.` In this manner different approaches can be realized and tested in a modular way.  Thus  this allows to implement an individual state filter within a paparazzi module: If the define `INS_USE_MODULE` is set in the airframe file  the corresponding init  reset  propagation  and update functions need to be implemented in the module and will be called by the state filter subsystem.  Similar to `guidance_module.h ` the header file `ins_module_int.h` includes the module headers and describing the interface as well.

Title: flight plans add call_once alias
Body: - `<call_once fun="x"/>` is an alias for `<call fun="x" loop="false"/>`  The idea is to make it easier and more clear how to call functions that do not return a bool and should only be called once.  Same as #1612 without the run alias

Title: flight plans add call_once and run aliases
Body: - `<call_once fun="x"/>` is an alias for `<call fun="x" loop="false"/>` - `<run fun="x"/>` is an alias for `<call fun="x" loop="true">` (hence same as call without loop explicitly specified)  The idea is to make this distinction more clear and encourage the use of `run` and `call_once` instead of `call`.  The previous discussion in #830 and #1606

Title: added the possibility to add a yaw rate limit to stabilization indi
Body: the yaw of a typical quadrotor easily saturates. One of the problems that occur when asking for a large change in yaw angle  is that the quadrotor can build up so much angular velocity in the yaw axis  that it can not physically slow down before reaching the yaw setpoint due to saturating. This will result in overshoot.   This can be helped by adding a yaw rate limit  which this PR does for the INDI controller.

Title: doc module description update
Fixing of optical flow algorithms
Body: The optical flow results from size divergence and linear fit are less good with the current master  as compared to older versions (e.g.  just after size divergence was added - 9ae722e294e7787da81060cd12d54d8e5c23b78a ).   In this commit  I add a number of small bug fixes  add some parameters  and add the old optical flow code in  which runs much faster when you don't use pyramids (it skips parts of the border  does not create padding  etc.). Like this people have the choice to run a multi-level pyramid LK optical flow if they have sufficient resources  or run the "flat" version if they don't.  Still  even with all the same settings and the same optical flow code as in the old commit  the optical flow results are not good. This is probably due to the drastically lower frame rate (when there is texture in sight 2-5 FPS as compared to 20/30 FPS for the old code). This difference lies in FAST9  of which the code has actually not changed... So for now I'm assuming something changed in the compilation of the FAST9 code that makes it slower. But I have not been able to pin it down. The additional flags etc. in video_thread.xml do not seem to make a difference.

Title: Removed spurious return from optic flow calculator

Title: Added an initial version of a texton module that represents the appea
Body: rance of an image with a texton distribution. In past work  we have used texton distributions for instance for obstacle detection. If the entropy of the texton distribution becomes low  this is typically an indication of a close obstacle. This "appearance variation cue" can be a good complement to using optical flow measurements for obstacle avoidance. There are may other uses for texton distributions though  while they are computationally quite cheap.

Title: Chibios integration
Body: Merging current work based on https://github.com/podhrmic/paparazzi/tree/rt_chibios into latest master.  The code is split into appropriate tasks  the tasks have different priorities and allocated certain memory space. As a result the code will never be fully compatible with non-rt paparazzi (some extra defines/guards are needed)  but having RTOS to run one big task with the whole autopilot doesn't really make sense.  Tested with Vectornav in HITL  sadly I don't have a board with working IMU ( @flixr @gautierhattenberger maybe you would be willing to test the baro/imu test cases?).   For GPS subsystems there needs to be defined another thread.  Features: - working drivers (uart  adc  i2c  spi  gpio) - working compilation with DEBUG/RELEASE options - test cases for individual drivers - working example of fixedwing RT code - switched to new ChibiOS 3.0 - works on Lisa MX only (for now)  Drawbacks: - currently fails to compile old Apogee example  because that one expects ChibiOS 2.6 (@gautierhattenberger are you still using the chibios3-libopencm3 hybdrid? )  Benefits: - faster and more efficient code (less CPU usage) - potentially safer code (tasks have different priorities)  Drawbacks: - longer compilation time - larger executable (although I haven't measured by how much)  The functionality is there  and the basic structure too  let me know your feedback!

Title: convert GPS subsystems to modules
Body: Converting the GPS subsystems should have the following benefits: - get rid of need for GPS registering (was introduced/needed for multi GPS support) - call init/event functions of each implementation from module instead of dispatcher in main - better documentation for each module (including configure/define options) - potentially add implementations specific settings that are autoloaded (gps reset?)  PRIMARY_GPS (and SECONDARY_GPS) now needs to be UPPERCASE (the first part of the ABI id  e.g. GPS_UBX) This is now only used/needed to resolve GpsId(PRIMARY_GPS) to e.g. GPS_UBX_ID  Also: - remove obsolete/non-functional gps_ublox_hitl and gps_ardrone2  Next steps?: - [x] make gps_sim and gps_nps modules and remove those targets from the "normal" modules - [x] add the sim modules ~~as dependencies so they can be auto-loaded~~ with the new autoload feature? - [x] call the `gps_periodic_check` from the modules for each implementation - [x] get rid of `gps_init` in main?  Feedback appreciated!

Title: Return utm alt as hmsl from gps helper function
Body: Although there is no defined reference for the utm altitude  in paparazzi (most in fixedwing firmware) it is more often than not assumed that alt is hmsl. I updated the helper functions from gps->utm to return alt with hmsl.   Additionally  I added additionally checks for the gps valid mask. Notably  if both UTM and LLA positions are not set utm is returned as (0 0 0  zone). Also  if gps.hmsl is not available we use the ellipsoid alt minus the geoid height at the original origin of the flight plan.

Title: filters delayed first order filter int

Title: Derotatation as part of the image pipeline
Body: Shoutout to everybody interested in image processing in Paparazzi! We often want to derotate our images  to track an object precisely  odometry  optical flow etc.  Today I ran some experiments: between the image capture and the end of optical flow the euler angles can easily get a difference of 17 degrees off (not that useful for optical flow). Even between the start of an image capture and the end (like in this pull request) there can be an offset of about 7.5 degrees.   I propose to let people choose how to deal with this interesting problem. One way to make it easy for them is to get the euler angels at the start of the image capture and at the end of the image capture.   Please let me know what you think about this solution  if you all agree that this is the way to go I will update the image functions in all modules to accept these new arguments.

Title: video_thread Improvements to video_thread performance

Other possible improvements to video_thread; - Dynamically change VISION_THREAD_NICE_LEVEL (via GCS setting) - Being able to have some vision functions run with less fps than others (e.g. use RunOnceEvery) - Improved fps regulation (e.g. smoothed average) - Provide the vision functions with access to current frame time and fps

Title: Updated contribution guidelines
Body: Hey everybody    Today we had a short discussion in our lab about how open source projects like Paparazzi should work. My proposal is to update our current workflow to get better software earlier in the Paparazzi project  and create issues for "smaller" fixes that are assigned to somebody.   Examples of what I propose would be done:  - we merge https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/pull/1745   then create issues assigned to Kevin to do everything at runtime.  - we merged https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/pull/1737 three days ago (since it was working perfectly)  but created multiple issues (i.e. I used the wrong casing  wrong variable names  that I should add rotation rates  that I made a mistake with the Linux defines etc.).   I am fully aware that having a pull request merged lowers your priority of working on it  but in my eyes this lower priority is justified by having faster improvements to our always changing autopilot. However  this would be a nice topic to discuss on!  Please tell me what you think about this proposed update.

Title: Threaded computer vision
Body: This pull request addresses improved computer vision functionality as discussed in #1735.  Quick recap; There is a desire to have some vision functions run with less fps than others. It would be great if the priorities can be set between vision functions. For example  textons should run at 5 Hz and optical flow at 30 Hz.  The current setup; For each video device a vision pipeline is created. Modules can attach to this pipeline and process the image in turn  and even modify the image. For example  a color filter can modify the image and one can then view the result in RTP stream. The problem is that  since the vision pipeline is sequential  some modules (like a costly marker detection algorithm) can stall the performance of other vision functions.  I made a proof of concept with @flixr's suggestion in the video_rtp_stream module. The module attaches to the vision pipeline with a routine that copies the image to a buffer if required. The module processes and sends the frames in a separate thread at 10 Hz.  TODO: - Abstract thread functionality into cv.h - Improve thread managing (starting/stopping module)  I think overall this is a good approach  but there are some drawbacks; - Copying the image costs time - The modified image is lost

Title: don t clean opencv_bebop with clean in main folder
Body: Today I ran test_all_confs and saw that the autonomous_dronerace airframe failed. It ended up that this was because my opencv_bebop submodule had never been initialised and it is not built automatically with make. It is not that useful for new developers wanting to work with opencv or is it good for the CI tests tht will test airframes that use opencv.  Due to the way the opencv_bebop is made it builds quite slowly the first time it checksout but it also tries to build some files every time you build. What I do with this commit is have it that the first time you build paparazzi it will download and build opencv_bebop but only try to rebuild the project if the install folder is missing from the subfolder. This means that the library will only be rebuilt if the user runs 'clean_opencv_bebop' from sw/ext or 'clean' from 'sw/ext/opencv_bebop' folder. Another pitfall of this is the CI build will likely take longer to run. as opencv will be fetched and built for each pull request.  This works for me but is not ideal  it would be great to only build the project if the 'submodule update' actually did something.  This also fast-forwards the submodule to the recent version.

Title: chibios recover from hard fault
Body: In case of crash of the autopilot  the mcu is restarted and the FBW thread is restarted (low level peripherals as well) but not the AP thread  assuming it is the source of the problem. It allows a safety pilot to take back the control of the plane in manual mode. Telemetry is also restarted  but the configuration of xbee modules (when relevant) is not done (already done  and skip the active for faster reboot).

See http://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/Paparazzi_Center/Evolutions for the main idea and development process. It can be tested by running the main paparazzi launcher with the `-python` option. Title: Plot shapes onto GCS
Body: This adds a shape plotting feature to the GCS. It is useful for plotting obstacles or image outlines.  Messages are sent over the ivy bus to the gcs. Currently circles and polygons can be plotted. Fill color is also available. Passing in "None" will disable fill.   In the future an optional text flag may be a good addition or a popup.  ``` xml   <message name="SHAPE" id="38">     <field name="id"     type="uint8"/>     <field name="linecolor"  type="string"/>     <field name="fillcolor"  type="string" values="color|none"/>     <field name="shape"  type="uint8" values="Circle|Polygon"/>     <field name="status" type="uint8" unit="bool" values="create|delete"/>     <field name="latarr"    type="int32[]"  unit="1e7deg" alt_unit="deg" alt_unit_coef="0.0000001"/>     <field name="lonarr"    type="int32[]"  unit="1e7deg" alt_unit="deg" alt_unit_coef="0.0000001"/>     <field name="radius" type="float" unit="m"/>     <field name="alt"    type="int32" unit="mm"/>   </message> ```

Title: opticflow module noisemeasurement fix
Body: Hi all   I noticed that the latest changes of adding a noise measurement to the optical flow module (for the intention of use of the hff filter) were not exactly producing the necessary results. This pull request is to at least make it flyable again in the current master  after I heard several complaints from our lab.  The most important issue was this: The more corners the algorithm tracked  the higher the noise measurement (est velocity error = tracked corners/ max_corners) becomes. However this is not wanted for the ins_hff  since there a higher estimated velocity error results in less trust in that measurementof the Kalman filter. I made a new equation  which actually gives a lower noise measurement with more corners.   In the future there needs to be a better  with optitrack groundtruth backed up  noise model  however this pull request will hopefully give an intermediate solution. I also added an optional median filter if the hff is not used or if more outliers needed to be filtered out.

Title: HITL initial commit
Body: This is an initial commit for a new Hardware-In-The-Loop simulator. Not meant to be merged as is  I am looking for feedback and help with improvement.  It was verified in real flight that the simulation is close enough so it can be trusted (we are actually publishing a paper about it soon).  **Features:** - simulates fixedwing flight with external INS (in this case Vectornav) - allows full flight simulation on the actual hardware (closest to real flight) - uses flight gear for visualisation - saves flight data both in the Ground Station (telemetry low frequency data) and as a csv file (high-frequency data)  **Limitations:** - fixedwing only - hardcoded position & model settings - has to be compiled separately (e.g. from Eclipse  not from Pprz center) - also requires boost  which some might consider as a limitation  **TO DO**: - [ ] integrate with paparazzi make process (so it includes the right flight plan data etc) - [ ] add VTOL option (?) - [ ] integrate Gaiga Environment simulator and Ivy messages listening (so you can control it easily)  As I said  feedback  suggestions and help implementing the last issue is very much appreciated!

Title: Optical flow filter and derotation fix
Body: Hi all   Here is some improvements to the optical flow code. - Kalman filter: I made a generic kalman filter just for the use of vision. The problem of using the HHF filter is that it also effect the reaction of the controls (for some reason there is too much dependency on the process model but I can't change the noise factors). I think that it is wise to filter vision results separate from the state filters. Right now it is implemented for optical flow  but later it can be used for tracking as well. I hope you will agree - derotation correction factor: there seems to be an error between the calculated derotation flow by the gyro and the calculated flow. Now it has been fitted together and for the bebop a correction term has to be added (credits to @mmoiozo for figuring this out).  This has been test flown with two bebops.  cheers    Kimberly

Nps update proof of concept of HITL SITL integration
Body: Continuation of #1789 this time using existing infrastructure (and glib).  The commit is rather large  but there are few separate commits that could be merged immediately: - 9a9c58bc4424594593a7f45f06a49376c5dde606 Added AggieAir control panel (simple) - support for higher baudrates & minor fixes in existing AP code (5e1576c27699fb5839ea44413d38acf673c1fa11 27393daecfefc01303b58935d4e72d822080f987 8dd3699f96a50466be965f05eb1c7f14cf10f5fe 2895ec12a5f65926642a3d7502bc6aced51e103c) - I added a "flight logger" module -> it is crucial for HITL  basically it sends telemetry messages (mainly COMMANDS) over a serial link. We also use it for logging (we have an Overo that saves data on SD card) 576169cdbe4c6e4116d32fcdf491cd5e3d766be6 - Then finally I wanted to be able to use NPS as SITL and HITL and have it modular - so far I have to add a flag to the airframe config file  I would prefer having a separate HITL target eventually (and rename NPS to SITL) - `nps_main.c` and `nps_hitl_main.c` are using threads and the timing/etc seems to work fine. It is mostly a proof of concept now  I am hoping to get some feedback from you before I clean it up more. Eventually I would like to have support for Xsens and other INS units (not just Vectornav).  I ll be on vacations next week  but I was hoping you could have a look at it in the meantime. @flixr @gautierhattenberger @deonblaauw ? Thanks.

abi fix endless loop if AbiBindMsgX is called twice for same event
Body: AbiBindMsgX should be called only once per abi_event struct.  Regardless  this tries to make it a bit more robust if you re-use the same abi_event for consecutive AbiBindMsgX calls:  If AbiBindMsgX is called multiple times _consecutively_  the event/callback is now only added if it is different from the last one added...  This should at least fix the endless loop since the event->next can't point to itself anymore...    Should fix #1924 in a rudimentary way... but would still be possible to bind multiple times using the same abi_event if another bind for the same message happens in between.  Bottom line: make sure that your code doesn't call AbiBindMsg with the same abi_event struct multiple times!

Title: Added define to disable rc direct fbw mode manual
Body: FBW mode (fly by wire) is a feature implemented on the Pixhawk  which (e.g. in case the AP crashes) enables the pilot to always override with RC control. This mode makes sense in case of e.g. fixed wing operation  which often don't necessarily require stabilization to be human-controllable. However  for a quadrotor such as the Iris+ it's useless  unless an IMU is added to the FBW processor such as in the Outback board. (and although the Pixhawk has two IMU's  both are connected to the AP)    The Pixhawk has an auxiliary processor (its got an STM32F1 FBW processor and an STM32F4 AP processor) to take care of the servo commands and RC receiver  and a main processor which runs the AP and stuff. The RC commands are passed on to the AP by the FBW. And before that happens  the FBW interprets the RC commands in order to not depend on the AP. So  if the RC command says FBW  the AP cannot override.    Currently there is no define to disable RC-Direct ( -->"FBW mode") from an airframe xml. This PR adds one.

Title: Added 2x3 way mode switch

Would be nice to have that in the rc xml instead of the airframe xml?

Title: update INDI tu use full control effecitvens matrix

This allows for online individual actuator control effectiveness estimation and inversion  as well as better saturation handling. The INDI controller as it was previous is renamed to 'simple'.  I think this is an essential step in making a more complete controller. This will allow us to do much better control allocation  for which we already did successful experiments. I will still update the code to make it look a bit better  for instance the hardcoded matrices should go of course. But perhaps you can already see if you like how the controller is interfacing with the actuators instead of commands  or if there is a better way.

Title: Set better battery levels Iris
navigation flight plan mandate call_once for functions that should only run once
Body: The `call` primitive of the flight plan can be used to repeatedly call a function until it returns false.  In most cases the function is only supposed to be called only once though...    This has led to a state where a lot of functions that are supposed to be called from the flight plan have an additional `return false` to make them `call`-able.    From just looking at the flight plan it is hard to determine if a function will indeed be only called once or is actually called each time the flight plan navigation is run until it is "done" (returns false).  To make this distinction more explicit and hopefully more clear (and the code cleaner)  one should use `call` only when really needed and `call_once` otherwise.    This PR removes the "dummy" `return false` from a lot of functions  hence mandating that `call_once` is used for them. Eventually we shouldn't have any cases like that anymore...  All flight plans were updated accordingly.    The most common case where `call` still has to be used are navigation routines a la `nav_x_run`.    This should be "backwards safe" (not backwards compatible) in the sense that if you try use `call` for a function that needs to be called with `call_once` (since it now returns void)  you will get an "invalid use of void expression" error:  ```  In file included from firmwares/rotorcraft/navigation.c:40:0:  /home/flixr/code/paparazzi/var/aircrafts/Quad_LisaMX/ap/generated/flight_plan.h: In function 'auto_nav':  /home/flixr/code/paparazzi/var/aircrafts/Quad_LisaMX/ap/generated/flight_plan.h:129:9: error: invalid use of void expression           if (! (NavKillThrottle())) {           ^  ```

Title: Pixracer
Body: This PR adds Paparazzi support for the [Pixracer](https://pixhawk.org/modules/pixracer) board. Basically  the Pixracer is a Pixhawk without the FBW side and with another set of sensors. Internally (in the PX4 stack as well)  it is called the px4fmu_4.0  whereas the normal Pixhawk has the px4fmu_2.4.    The Pixracer has been mounted in the Splash drone  and by means of the MPU9250 IMU  a Spektrum RC  3DR power module and a XBee datalink it has been tested to fly nicely in ATT mode. NAV test flight is on the todo list  but should work as well.    Not supported:  - The ICM-20608 IMU  - The temp compensation on the HMC5983 magneto  - Usage of the microSD  - ESP8266 flashing over wifi    Known problems:  - The Spektrum soft binding does not seem to work yet. All the pins and powers are cycled correctly  still the binding won't take.    Big thanks to @OpenUAS for laying the foundation for this PR.

Title: Generic rotation matrix for mounted stereocamera

The stereocam in combination with the lisa-s  the new lisa MXs  and the ardrone are usually mounted on there in different direction (facing backwards  forwards and downwards). Before  we had to constantly double check the direction of the velocities to transform that manually to body fixed coordinates  which was very prone to mistakes. Same goes with the derotation of optical flow on the stereocam.     This addition should make it easier and more generic for platforms with the mounted stereocamera.

Title: Disable all LEDs
Body: Add a general led_disable that will disable the LEDs configured by the led_init function. In most case it will set the corresponding GPIO as input with high impedance (no pull-up/down).    The aim of this functionality is to reduce at the maximum the energy consumption when closing the log files after power down on Apogee and Chimera boards. This will leave more time (with the big capacitor) to flush all data and avoid file corruption.

Title: Robird
Body: This PR adds Robird  which is a flappy wing vehicle resembling a falcon with a Pixhawk autopilot.     1. It has some R7008SB SBUS2 receiver   which is different than some other SBUS2 receivers  which is different then SBUS receivers. To boring to go into  but apparantely PX4 has a better implementation so I borrowed some info there. This works fine for this equipment  but would be interesting to test on current sbus stuff.  2. The bird can glide pretty well  but only if the wing is locked in a certain position. I created a module  which reads a wing position sensor  which can lock the wing exactly right. However  this is done by setting the thrust to a fixed value just before attempting to lock it (there are some speed inertia dynamics to account for)  and then after a rotation sets the thrust to 0 (which actively breaks the motor). I could not think of a nice way to do everything from the module code  so  I needed to change the autopilot a bit. It's working fine  but if anyone can think of something better...?    Its not been flight tested yet as that is scheduled for over two weeks  so I would like to add this to pprz already now.

Title: Wind estimation
Body: Add a wind estimation algorithm  based on Unscented Kalman Filter for real time estimation of all 3 components. The computation is done in a ChibiOS thread so it runs in parallel of the autopilot. The algorithm itself is generated from a Matlab/Simulink model.    This module can also serves as an example of integration of generated code and ChibiOS threads with mutex and signals synchronization.    Some extra tools and modification:  - angle of attack and sideslip update in NPS  - second angle of attack (e.g. sideslip) in aoa_pwm driver  - Meso-NH reader to feed NPS with realistic meteorological (wind) data    The algorithm itself is still an ongoing research topic and might be updated in the future. It shouldn't be used for "normal" operations.

Title: modules baro_board as module
Body: Since in the long run we want to move more stuff to modules and eventually also convert subsystems to modules to be more flexible and have less explicit calls in main  I started with changing the baro_board subsystem (which is actually automatically added to fixedwing and rotorcraft firmware at the moment) to a module.  So if you try to use this  you have to add the baro_board.xml module (otherwise it will warn you if your board normally has a baro onboard).  Only the microjet_lisa_m and quadrotor_lisa_mx are updated to have the baro_board module loaded right now...  This is mostly meant to have something to look at for discussion about how we should handle things like automatically loading the correct drivers according to the board that you have.  This module does basically the same as the subsystem makefile before: a raw makefile section that needs to list all available boards with their baro options.  Maybe we can instead think of another way to have some modules automatically loaded  so we really have only one module for each baro?

Title: MAG_CALIB_UKF Online magnetomer calibration using unscented Kalman filter
Body: Magnetometer performance on the bebop2 has been below optimal. Several fixes have provided increased usability (#1836 #1864) however they require calibration and regular re-calibration of the magnetometer and as far as I heard do not allow for long duration flights due to magnetometer drift (@OpenUAS @bartremes)    In this module an unscented kalman filter is implemented based on [TRICAL](http://github.com/sfwa/TRICAL) to calibrate the magnetometer online. This should prevent magnetometer drift during flight.     I have been testing this non-flying on several bebop2's and it seems to provide accurate calibration. However due to weather conditions I haven't been able to do any NAV flight tests.     It would be awesome if anybody else with access to either bebop1 or bebop2 could verify this.    **Current limitations:**    - Currently this is only tested on the bebop2 since it is the only platform I am currently able to test.  - I have not flown in NAV mode yet due to windy conditions in the Netherlands. During RC ATT flight the bebop does provide the correct heading  - The UKF should also be able to correct for motor current disturbances so mag_current_coef shouldn't be necessary (this hasn't been thoroughly investigated yet!)

Title: fix loss of information due to quality variable type declaration in OF ABI
Body: To fix issue #1973  I changed the abi.xml file to treat quality as a float instead of a uint8_t instead.    This currently seems the best option.   Alternatively I could address the FIXME in the AbiSendMsgOPTICAL in opticflow_module.c:  "// FIXME  scale to some quality measure 0-255"    However  if we change the float noise_measurement in the struct opticflow_result_t to uint8_t noise_measurement to optimize for speed  while multiplying the relevant variables by 255  other code  i.e. the filtering in the edgeflow algorithm would break as float noise_measurement is used in calculations.    **NB** I also updated the type declaration in optical_flow_landing.c to prevent compile errors.

Title: Edge flow fixes
Body: Each commit contains different fixes for different problems.  Most fixes are clear by the commit message  if not please ask why I did certain things.    Note that for the RESOLUTION_FACTOR in opticflow_calculator.c I'm quite sure it is implemented now as it was intended. However I am not fully sure it is sufficient  as information is lost earlier regardless due to the use of integers instead of floats.    Apart from those I have a few remarks/questions with respect to things that might improve speed a bit  or remain a possible problem. However I have not fixed them as I am not sure if my proposed solution is valid/matters.    1)  I believe line 201 in edge_flow.c is useless  given line 181:  https://github.com/ETitus/paparazzi/blob/EdgeFlow_fixes/sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/lib/vision/edge_flow.c#L201  Removing line 201 might result in a slightly faster run?    2)  looking at line 124 and 143 in edge_flow.c  the for loop goes over c=-1  c=0 and c=1. But the loop does nothing useful per definition for c=0  because Sobel[c + 1] * something will always be 0 as Sobel[0+1]=Sobel[1]=0.  I am not sure how much  or actually little computation time this will save  but having the for loop only loop c=-1 and c=1 could prevent useless computations.  https://github.com/ETitus/paparazzi/blob/EdgeFlow_fixes/sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/lib/vision/edge_flow.c#L124    3)  If one is to switch between LK and EF frequently the if statement in line 451 in opticflow_calculator.c is run multiple times  mallocing space  that is not being freed somewhere.  This can either be moved to the init function  and set to 0 when the if in 451 is run.  https://github.com/ETitus/paparazzi/blob/EdgeFlow_fixes/sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/opticflow/opticflow_calculator.c#L451    The same goes for the if in line 240  where 2 images are created and not freed upon switching away.    https://github.com/ETitus/paparazzi/blob/EdgeFlow_fixes/sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/opticflow/opticflow_calculator.c#L240

Adding new modes might works thought.    One of the main changes is the modification of the AP mode name to match the rotorcraft firmware. It makes the code generation easier.

Title: Fixed copilot module
Body: Now it works both with rotorcraft and fixedwing firmwares.    The problem is that the waypoints are handled differently in each  and Copilot has to process the WP_MOVED message.    I wanted to take care of this at the makefile level  rather than having a bunch of `ifdefs` but I needed to pass the information about which firmware is being used (hence added the `FIRMWARE` variable in the makefile). It would be nice if this was eventually handled by the generators and I didn't have to use the `<raw>` section in the module xml file  but it works fine for now.

Title: In KILL mode the servos are set to preload with 0 pulse such that th
Body: e last pulse is finished and it is safe to flash the vehicle. This will prevent (stupid) servos to go to the outer position upon flashing. Tested and works.  As a side effect  servos will not move from their current position in kill mode  and can be moved by hand. I don't think this is a problem  it even makes more sense for kill mode.

Body: next batch of coverity fixes  this time only NPS code

Title: Added a Region of Interest feature to the fast9 corner detector and fixed a reallocation bug
Body: - Bugfix : If the reallocation of the `ret_corners` array caused it to be moved in memory  the calling function would lose track of the new corners because the pointer was only passed by value into the `fast9_detect()`. Now it is passed by reference to avoid this.    - Minor change : Local variable `corner_cnt` of `fast9_detect()` changed to `uint16_t` instead of `uint32_t`.    - _RoI_ feature not used in optic flow calculations for now  but will be when feature management is implemented.

Title: Exponential gain landing pull request
Body: I implemented the exponentially decreasing gain strategy for optical flow landing that we describe in:    H.W. Ho  G.C.H.E. de Croon  E. van Kampen  Q.P. Chu  and M. Mulder (submitted)  Adaptive Control Strategy for Constant Optical Flow Divergence Landing   <https://arxiv.org/abs/1609.06767>    I also rewrote the module to replace duplicate parts of code with function calls  hopefully considerably improving the readability and expandability of the module. I tested all the functionalities in the TU Delft Cyberzoo this morning on a Bebop 2.

Title: Add Gazebo simulation to NPS
Body: This pull request adds Gazebo 7/8 as a Flight Dynamics Model for NPS. Unlike JSBsim  Gazebo can provide a 3D environment and camera sensors. The video_thread module has been modified so that Gazebo's camera images can be used during simulation. This means that it is now possible to perform closed-loop simulations with vision-based control schemes.    Changes:  - Addition of Gazebo FDM    - conf/modules/fdm_gazebo.xml    - sw/simulator/nps/nps_fdm_gazebo.cpp    - conf/Makefile.nps  - Modification of video_thread_nps and pc_sim board to simulate cameras    - sw/airborne/boards/pc_sim.h    - sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/video_thread_nps.c    - sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/video_thread_nps.h    - sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/viewvideo_nps.c  - Example world and model for Gazebo    - conf/simulator/gazebo/models/ardrone/model.config    - conf/simulator/gazebo/models/ardrone/ardrone.sdf    - conf/simulator/gazebo/world/ardrone.world  - Example files for Paparazzi    - conf/airframes/examples/ardrone2_gazebo.xml    - conf/conf_example.xml  - Changed .xml files to allow compilation for nps    - conf/modules/cv_colorfilter.xml    - conf/modules/video_rtp_stream.xml    Known issues:  - Rotorcraft only  control surfaces are not yet supported.  - AHRS/INS need to be bypassed as these do not yet function correctly. Probable causes are the lack of atmospheric measurements and/or incorrect magnetometer readings from Gazebo.  - Video streaming might not work correctly  see issue [2068](https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/issues/2068).  - Starting from version 8  Gazebo has an atmospheric model incl. wind  drag  lift etc.. This is not used yet.    Demo:  1. Install gazebo 7 or 8: `sudo apt-get install gazebo8 libgazebo8-dev`.  2. Run ./start.py to select conf/conf_example.xml and control_panel_example.xml  3. Select the ardrone_gazebo aircraft  build for nps and start the simulation.  4. Run `gzclient` in a new terminal window to view the simulation.  5. Control the UAV using the GCS as usual.  6. Connect to the video RTP stream as described on the [wiki](https://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/AR_Drone_2#Option_1:_Simple_low_quality_MJPEG_over_RTP)    More usage information can be found in conf/modules/fdm_gazebo.xml.

Title: First shot towards a separate HITL target
Body: @gautierhattenberger I am trying to add HITL as a separate target so it is easier to use.    The idea is that `hitl` is de facto `nps` target  except it has a different name (and uses a few different files). So I want to have `nps_common.makefile` and then `nps.makefile` and `hitl.makefile` (see below).    Then I have to have a toplevel `Makefile.hitl` that only calls `Makefile.nps` and that should be it - right?    I can'get it to compile  I suspect there is some change with generators that I have to add the target to?

Title: WLS control allocation
Body: This is a pull request for a control allocation scheme  made by Daan Hppener  a student of mine. It allows you to specify priorities for different control objectives through a weighting in the cost function. This is why it has weighted least squares (WLS) in the name. Prioritizing parts of the control objective (pitch and roll over yaw for instance) is important for stable flight when there are saturations. Normally  the optimal control input can be found with the pseudo-inverse. However  when there are saturations  WLS-control allocation will satisfy the important parts of the control objective at the cost of the unimportant parts.    The optimal solution for this cost function is found using the active set method  which requires solving multiple least squares problems. For this we are using a (trimmed down) library from John Burkardt (http://people.sc.fsu.edu/~jburkardt/cpp_src/r8lib/r8lib.html). I wasn't sure what header we need for these files.    Probably I can still improve some stuff here and there  but I wanted to get the ball rolling with this pr...

Title: Revert WLS control allocation
Body: Reverts paparazzi/paparazzi#2075    There was not enough time for review. The pull request will be resubmitted.

Title: Fast9 feature management and FPS setting on optical flow
Body: This pull request tries to make the Lucas-Kanade optical flow algorithm more robust and extentable by keeping track of the same features over time instead of re-detecting every frame. Re-detection will now happen when tracked corners reach a low threshold  and only in the region(s) that have a low amount of corners.  It also fixes the already existing method which detected corners on the new frame and then projected them to the previous one to track them again.  The last commit introduces an FPS parameter to all computer vision modules such that the video listeners that they attach to the camera with the `cv_add_to_device` function can operate at a lower frequency than the camera frame rate. This can be useful in cases like the optical flow where a high frame rate could accumulate error. Note that many of those modules could not be compiled out of the box  but the feature was added so that the call to the `cv_add_to_device` would not be a source of error later on.

Title: Poly survey via Guidance Vector Field addition
Body: Some updates regarding the Guidance Vector Field (I will update the wiki accordingly).    - The gains 'ke' and 'kd' are not "global" anymore and each trajectory has its own set of gains. If the user runs a mission with different trajectories  then there is not need to change the gains on the fly anymore  e.g. poly survey (see later). The user can also tune the gains separately and save them in its airframe.    - More primitives regarding ellipses  sin and lines have been added. In particular  now there is 'gvf_segment' where the aircraft tracks a segment defined by two points.    - The set NAV now has 'nav_survey_polygon_gvf_run()'  which does exactly the same as 'nav_survey_polygon_run()'  but employing the GVF instead of the Carrot. One of the advantages is that during the segments  the aircraft really tracks the line and it is not going to a waypoint (Carrot).

Title: Optic flow changes
Body: This pull request tries to make the Lucas-Kanade optical flow algorithm more robust and extentable by keeping track of the same features over time instead of re-detecting every frame. Re-detection will now happen when tracked corners reach a low threshold  and only in the region(s) that have a low amount of corners.  It also fixes the already existing method which detected corners on the new frame and then projected them to the previous one to track them again.  The second commit introduces an FPS parameter to all computer vision modules such that the video listeners that they attach to the camera with the `cv_add_to_device` function can operate at a lower frequency than the camera frame rate. This can be useful in cases like the optical flow where a high frame rate could accumulate error. Note that many of those modules could not be compiled out of the box  but the feature was added so that the call to the `cv_add_to_device` would not be a source of error later on.

Title: Bebop firmware 4 06 seems to work fine tested with manual flying
flight_plan add binding to ABI messages from flight plan
Body: This feature allows to create an automatic binding to a ABI message  while specifying the list of variable names ('_' are ignored).  A local (static) variable is updated to the latest value each time a new  message is received and it can be read in any flight plan instruction.    Example of usage:     <variables>    <abi_binding name="VELOCITY_ESTIMATE" vars="_  vx  vy  vz  _"/>   </variables>    please not the in this example  the first and the last variable are  ignored but the number of variable must match the number of fields in  ABI messages description (conf/abi.xml).    An extra attribute 'id' allows to set a specific sender ID (by default  ABI_BROADCAST).

Title: Air to air gps
Body: This is used by the traffic info module to have position of surrounding aircraft at higher rate and lower latency.  Based on PPRZLINK v2.

Title: Flight plan functions for autopilot mode guided
Body: This pull request has a new paparazzi module  which includes some basic functions that can be used from the flight plan directly when the autopilot is in guided mode. This enables the possibility to also use the flight plan when no perfect 3D fix is known (like GPS or OptiTrack)  since most are focused position waypoints. Since indoor autonomous flight is becoming more common application  this module can be very helpful as it turns the flight plan into a state machine  which can reactively respond to its environment. I have been using this principle for my flights for a while now so therefore I want to merge it into paparazzi master branch.    This pull request includes:  -  flight_plan_guided module  - example airframe with the module included (for gazebo simulator)  -  example flight plan which uses the module (I added it to the conf_example.xml  so you can try it out yourselves)  -  adjusted the color filter to send an ABI message if an color (obstacle) is detected. It serves as an example how this detection can be used in the flight plan.    I hope that you also find this module useful and please comments if there are some issues or if it has to be adjusted for more general use within paparazzi

Title: BMP v2 swd flashing issue fix for lisa mxs

Title: Attitude viz message and no_rc takeoff for indi
Body: - The attitude visualizer message was missing from indi_simple  - With INDI it was not possible to take off without RC in NAV mode (also not in sim). This was because the in_flight heuristic depends on the thrust variable  which is not really used with INDI.    Things that depend on the thrust variable:  - Current estimation  - in_flight heuristic -> which I again use to determine if the controller should run or not    This commit at least let you take off...

Title: added outlier detector to bebop sonar
Body: This looks for large changes in sonar readings and delays sending the new measurements till the rate of change of the new measurement compared to the last sent measurement drops below a certain fixed threshold. This was found to be necessary to prevent large outliers from being propagated through the ins (the sonar is typically trusted quite heavily).  This outlier detector will also delay the propagation of true vertical height transitions for eg when flying over a table  the gradient threshold has been chosen to remove temporary outliers and not delay true transitions for very long.

Title: Allocation merge
Body: This is a continuation of #2075 because I would like to give ample time for people to review this. @OpenUAS if you would like to test  I welcome that very much  but I think it should be possible to use this branch for that.

Title: F3 and X Vert support
Body: Adds support for:  1. STM32F373x  2. The Horizon Hobbies Eflite X-Vert VTOL (based on the STM32F373xC)  3. STM32F303x (preliminary)  4. The F3 Discovery board (based on the STM32F303)    All are based on Chibios. In order to fit the RAM memory footprint on the 32K RAM of the STM32F37  the thread working area sizes have been reduced. It all seems to work without fault  so I don't think it is necessary to increase the size for larger chips such as the F7.   Another thing is that the PPRZ_TRIG_CONST needed to be defined as CONST. This placed the sin integer lookup table on flash. The other defines such as PPRZ_TRIG_INT_COMPR_FLASH do not seem to have any effect. Of course  the new define PPRZ_TRIG_INT_USE_FLOAT also works.    The x-vert has been flight tested. It can hover manually. Further steps (autonomous  forward flight) are planned. A wiki page about the x-vert is in the works.    Known problems:  The X-vert ESCs provide motor feedback  but this is not yet read out  The X-vert may have a current sensor  but it is not yet read out  The X-vert board has an CYRF chip for radio control  but this is not supported yet in this PR.  The Chibios stm32F37 implementation has a problem with the hard FPU. When enabled  totally weird results happen.

Title: vertical reference frames for altitude height
Body: Please suggest ideas & problems as we go or add a commit yourself if you have an idea.  ---  Altitude/Height are still difficult in paparazzi: one reason for problems is that way-points/limits do not store how the alt/height was originally intended (relative/absolute/barometric). While conversions in paparazzi are fine  it depends on timing (e.g. compile time/before geo-init/after geoinit) and other constraints like e.g. the accuracy of the ground level defined in the flightplan if or not the intended goal is achieved.  _Definitions_:  [Paparazzi Wiki: Altitude/Height](http://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/Demystified/Altitude_and_Height)  ![Ellipsoid-Geoid](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Geoida.svg/730px-Geoida.svg.png)  **GPS:** - alt = above ellipsoid (2) (which is NOT sea level and is not used in aviation) - hmsl = above sea level (5) = geoid = aviation altitude  ![Height/Alt](http://www.ulmpassion.ch/index_html_m73f33271.png)  **Aviation:** - alt = above mean sea level  which is more or less equal to the geoid (neglecting the ocean surface topography) - height = above local terrain (in paparazzi: SRTM)  **Conclusion** In case barometric and gps altitude are perfectly converted then: - ellipsoid = gps.alt = never used in aviation - geoid = gps.hmsl = aviation-altitude = QNH altitude - flight level = altidute in case the pressure at sea level was 1013.25 - QFE = height above 'geo-init' or take-off field - aviation height = height above local terrain = SRTM (not available onboard yet in paparazzi) - height above obstacle = sonar/radar height  All of the above can have slightly different scalings depending on the sensor used.  The idea of this pull request is to be able to set waypoint and limiting heights using any reference: e.g. set WP height above terrain -> using SRTM model the altitude changes with position. Or when waypoints have a QFE height  then skipping geo-init is made impossible. Or in the indoor flight arena  waypoints height above ground can be set.

Title: Opticalflow Fix optical flow nans when using feature management
Body: Amongst others  this PR does:  - Fix nans when using feature management  - Use filtered agl instead of raw  - Use change in angle for derotation rather than rate  - Removed unused variables and general clean up  - Removed vision only Kalman filter  hff is preferred method.  - Ran code style    messages.xml is just a place holder till the PR is approved.

Title: ins updated hff to accept velocity as only input and add bias
Body: This adds a bias estimate to the hff filter and allows the filter to run with only velocity inputs as well as position estimates. This also adds the possibility to have a local position estimate added to the ins.     This has been tested with a bebop 2 and a pocket drone. It is important to define the noise characteristics to suit the drone being used but once done the performance is quite good.

Added the capability to turn off the GPS  useful for testing indoor environments.  Added some additional debugging capabilities.    I came across a strange warning that I didn't see before:  cc1plus: warning: command line option '-std=gnu99' is valid for C/ObjC but not for C++    I can't find where the cflags are being added to the CXXFLAGS but this warning is also in the current master. Any ideas?

Title: Change stereocamera message parser to pprzlink

With this I am also squeezing the functionality of stereocam2state and state2stereocam into the stereocam file. This should help with maintenance of docs and code. I updated the airframes that used the stereocam and added an airframe of my own to ensure that this module is included in tests in the future.    This does break the droplet module however. This implementation of the droplet will be replaced by a better one in the coming weeks.

Also moves the computation of the covariance and mean to the statistics file in the math library. I also cleaned up a warning in the optical flow calculator with the shadow variable name 'state'. @guidoAI can you take a look at this?    @gautierhattenberger I made a stat.c file and added it to the rotorcraft makefile. Is this alright? I thought it is better if it compiled than in the header...

Title: Fixed the EdgeFlow Divergence computation Sign Error
Body: When computing flow and divergence with Edgeflow  there is a comment saying:    /* Save Resulting flow in results     * Warning: The flow detected here is different in sign     * and size  therefore this will be divided with     * the same subpixel factor and -1 to make it on par with     * the LK algorithm of t opticalflow_calculator.c     * */  Next the flow vectors are multiplied by -1. However  the divergence wasn't multiplied by -1  a quick test when flying up and down and computing divergence with both LK and EF at the same time confirmed there was a sign difference.  This pull request fixes that.    @kirkscheper This is the pull request I was referring to.

Title: Make dt_ global variables static in mission and energy_ctrl
Body: Fixes #2136 as recommended by @kirkscheper

Title: Fixed OCaml type inference Fixed tilt handling
Body: thanks @hendrixgr for pointing out a type inference issue.  Commit also sets the default pan to (90 deg) camera straight pointing down.

Title: nps load aircraft into gazebo at run time actuator handling
Body: This enables gazebo to grab the quadrotor configuration from the airframe file and load up the correct model. This also ensures that the same yaw configuration is used for the simulator as is defined in the motor_mixing to reduce possible user error. Now the only thing is that the order of the actuator names still has to be correct.    Secretly  this also refractors how GPS is ignored in nps. As well as replaces course with heading when GPS_DATALINK is used so that nps correctly copies reality when using natnet/optitrack.    @knmcguire and @tomvand can you take a look here and let me know if there are any issues.

Title: Single udp socket
Body: Only create one socket for sending and receiving  instead of two where you use one only to send and the other only to receive. There should be no reason/need to create two separate ones...  Also add udp_socket.[ch] to make it easier to use only the UDP sockets without the UART like mcu_periph/udp interface around it. Provides the functions: - `udp_socket_create` - `udp_socket_send` - `udp_socket_recv` - `udp_socket_recv_dontwait`  Which should make it easy to replace the other udp socket wrappers used in e.g. modules/computer_vision and hence address #1079

Title: start move list of conf to library for re use in other tools
tools add the code to run onboard the ARDrone for STDMA a2a coms
Body: This adds the capability to run a helper on the ardrone to communicate with a bluetooth dongle in the usb port of the drone. The code implements Self-Organized Time Division Multiple Access protocol which allows the vehicles to broadcast messages directly other drones without the need for a ground station. This dongle should be combined with the extra_pprz_dl module with:  ``` <module name="extra_dl.xml">       <configure name="EXTRA_DL_PORT" value="UDP1"/>       <define name="UDP1_PORT_IN" value="5000"/>       <define name="UDP1_PORT_OUT" value="5001"/>       <define name="UDP1_HOST" value="127.0.0.1"/> </module> ```  I am not sure if this is the correct place for this so please advise.

Title: ACT FAST
Body: This is a new method to efficiently detect corners in large images  such as those obtained from the Parrot Bebop 1 and 2. The method is inspired by the method in the article: de Croon  G.C.H.E.  and Nolfi  S. (2013  May). Act-corner: Active corner finding for optic flow determination. In Robotics and Automation (ICRA)  2013 IEEE International Conference on (pp. 4679-4684). IEEE.    The main idea of this particular implementation  called ACT-FAST  is that actively scanning the image allows to:  1. Skip uniform areas in the image. If these areas are contiguous  many non-corners will never be evaluated.  2. Follow edges. Typically  following an edge will bring an agent to a corner.    These two simple rules lead to a significant lower number of corner evaluations  while still detecting a reasonable number of corners. Moreover  since the agents scanning the image start on a grid  corners will be quite well-distributed over the image. Each step of the agent starts by classifying the agent location as a corner or not with FAST. For bigger images (e.g.  640 x 640)  the computational advantage of ACT-FAST over the normal  exhaustive application of FAST becomes significant (in the order of a factor > 10). On a Bebop 2 I measured a processing time of ~0.003 seconds compared to ~0.04 seconds for exhaustive FAST corner checking.     The code here is part of the following publication:  de Croon  G.C.H.E. "ACT-FAST: efficiently finding corners by actively exploring images."  in submission.

The link to the library and Arduino build file is provided in the module description. An ABI message with the received information is then broadcasted.

Title: Added key generator for asymmetric keys

Makefile command:   ```  $(AIRFRAME_H) : $(CONF)/$(AIRFRAME_XML) $(CONF_XML) $(AIRCRAFT_MD5)  ...    $(Q)cargo run --manifest-path $(PAPARAZZI_HOME)/sw/tools/key_generator/Cargo.toml --release $(AC_GENERATED)  ```    Requires Rust and Cargo (get it from https://www.rustup.rs/ )

Title: Add rangesensor module
Body: This pull request includes several items relating to adding range sensors to MAVs:    - Compatibility to read out the new ToF laser ring through UART (designed by @dewagter)  - Adding laser range sensor array to gazebo models (Bottom laser range sensor is send through like a sort of sonar)  - Made an module that creates a velocity forcefield based on those sensors  which can be used within guided flight.  - Make SWD_NOPWR default for lisa_mxs boards  - Converted all tabs in the gazebo models to double spaces  - Dynamically add sensors to gazebo vehicles depending on the modules used  - Added simple square environment for collision avoidance navigation testing  - Added some needed math functions    This replaces #2114 due to conflicting files.

Title: Fix incorrect in flight acceleration measurements in Gazebo
Body: This PR fixes a bug in the accelerations measured by gazebo.    Gazebo's GetWorldLinearAccel() did not seem to take the ardrone's velocity_decay (drag) into account  instead it measured the drone's acceleration *without drag* which resulted in incorrect measurements  in-flight (the drone's acceleration in world frame did not go to zero when the drone reached its steady-state velocity).    Fixed by manually deriving the drone's world velocity over time  as in [Gazebo's own IMU implementation](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/e26144434b932b4b6a760ddaa19cfcf9f1734748/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ImuSensor.cc-370).    Created an issue for Gazebo [here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2363/linear-velocity_decay-not-included-in-link).

Title: Drag based velocity estimator
Body: This PR adds a new module 'dragspeed' that uses the accelerometer to estimate the drag acting on the quadrotor  which is then transformed back into its velocity. This allows the velocity to be estimated using the IMU *without integration*. For usage instructions see sw/airborne/modules/dragspeed/readme.pdf.    **This PR requires the DRAGSPEED message in pprzlink  see [the corresponding PR](https://github.com/paparazzi/pprzlink/pull/62).**    Example result:  ![total_filter_0_8](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5869151/31892285-ee384d8c-b808-11e7-8dfd-24138236f878.png)

Title: Fix redundant rotorcraft_guided_flightplan

The one in the root flight plan folder causes a compilation error due to a missing variable _ in the abi_binding (try the ardrone_flightplan_guided_gazebo aircraft in the tudelft conf).    This PR replaces the root rotorcraft_guided_flightplan by the one in the tudelft folder  the one in the tudelft folder is deleted. The conf's that referred to this file are changed to point to the correct location.

Title: Set Gazebo world in flight plan
Body: Since the flight plan specifies the "mission" of the UAV  including waypoint coordinates etc.  it seems to be a better place to select the Gazebo world than the airframe file.    With this pull request  an additional attribute `gazebo_world` can be added to the top-level `flight_plan` XML element. When the Gazebo world is specified in the flight plan  it takes priority over the define in the airframe file or the default empty.world.  This allows a single airframe file to be used in different environments.

Title: tmtc add pprzlink_proxy tool
Body: PPRZLINK Proxy is a tool to allow multiple aircraft simulations  with air-to-air communication using the PPRZLINK v2 protocol  using UDP.  As aircarft can't be identified by their IP addresses (most of the  time  all simulators are running on the same computer)  each agent (GCS   aircraft) are using different ports and the mapping between ports and IDs  is done by this tool.

Title: Circular formations More elegant script and examples
Body: I have rewritten (and tested) the python script for the circular formations (centralized version). It is prettier now xD. I have also added two examples for the configuration file.    This script sends two messages for setting 'gvf_ell_a' and 'gvf_ell_b'. Because in this version we deal only with circles  both messages have the same payload (the radius of the circle to be tracked). However  it is possible to cover the more general case of ellipses with a small modification  and then 'gvf_ell_a' and 'gvf_ell_b' will be different.    This modification is something that I have to think a bit how to include it :P. If the bandwitdh is an issue  then the user should use the module for the decentralized version.    edit  -----    I have also rewritten (and tested) the initialization of tables for the decentralized case. Now both cases  centralized and decentralized  can use the same config files thanks to jetson.

Title: ARDrone vision fix
Body: The ARDrone in paparazzi Master was flying at 2-5 FPS  which is insufficient for proper optical flow.  Upon investigating it turns out that this is the case since https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/pull/2079  where the feature management was introduced  later fixed in https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/pull/2087. However the feature management is turned off by default.    Furthermore the pyramid was set two 2 layers standard.    Testing on an ARDrone and Bebop alongsides showed that the Bebop had no issue with the code and was still flying arround 90 FPS(camera maximum) while the ARDrone dropped from 30-60 FPS(camera max) to 2-5 FPS.     In this pullrequest I set the pyramid back to 0  which improved FPS to about 10-15 FPS. I also tried to turn on feature management  which had the same result. Combining these two changes returned the FPS to 30-60 FPS for an ARDrone.    I changed the setting in all ARDrone conf files that include the vision  to leave Bebop untouched.

Title: added a divide by 0 failsafe
Body: Referencing back to https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/issues/2097#issuecomment-320302913 again  there is still a divide by 0 possible and actually happening.  If for all samples in    for (uint16_t sample = 0; sample < n_samples; sample++)   distance_1 is 0  then the newly introduced used_samples remains 0  leading to a division by 0 in the mean_f function in:  https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/blob/master/sw/airborne/modules/computer_vision/opticflow/size_divergence.c#L118  This value then messes up filters where the size_divergence is used  for example OF_Landing and forthcoming OF_Hover.    The suggested fix sets the mean_divergence to 0. Though I am NOT sure if this is the correct behavior to fix it.

Title: Qtcreator indent size fix and added upload feature

Title: replace nav_utm_xxx0 with state utm_origin_f
Body: The utm position seems to use nav_utm_zone0 to compute position when a utm gps isn't present. nav_utm_XXX0 are only updated with unit_t nav_reset_utm_zone(void) which was never called so seems like this won't work when changing zones.  All ins modules set the state.tum_origin_f directly so it seems more logical to use that variable instead of the nav variables.  Additionally  the rotorcraft nav doesn't use similar variables so I thought this may help with future merging of navigation firmware.  Note: This implementation only removes the nav variables  there still isn't an implementation to check the zone and update the utm_origin_f when the zone changes.

A demo module is using the data to track an object or a face by controlling the heading of a rotorcraft. This demo could be improved in the future to replace the very basic control / heading estimation by a proper PID controller and/or target position estimator.
