Title: Arming status msg
Body: After spending (again #1011 ) an hour or so figuring out why my drone would not take off  only to find that a small accidental trim in the joystick is not allowed by the arming procedure  I thought to finally create a message such that this info can be shown to the user.    The accompanying pprzlink PR: https://github.com/paparazzi/pprzlink/pull/75    Currently only the arming by throttle is fully done: the kill-switch-arming is not implemented  and  the yaw-arming is not tested.    About the yaw arming: the procedure has changed slightly: before this PR centering all sticks was only required during the initialization state. I think it should be required during all arming steps  otherwise it can easily happen that the drone will violently flip at arming. I think it has happened to me often actually. Now that the user is informed about why the drone is not arming  I think that cancels the biggest disadvantage of this extra hassle.  Let me know if this is acceptable  and I will try to test yaw arming ASAP as well.    Question: the throttle arming checks the mode and whether the AP has unarmed  yaw-arming doesn't do that... Does not seem correct...?      In the future I suggest to also not allow arming the drone if the battery is critical or outside the geofence. Any other cases?

Title: Pprzlink update

Title: Monocular Optical Flow hover
Body: This pull requests adds my MSc thesis work into Paparazzi:  https://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid%3A6e3ce742-a974-491d-97c2-1cafc090b3d9  It contains a module that uses monocular vision to estimate the height and/or automatically tune the controller of a hovering drone to the proper gains without using the sonar.      Included are properly tuned airframes for ARDrone2 and Bebop 1  functions for monocular hover and a more general function file. The latter contains functions that are also used in Optical Flow Landing  except without hardcoded variable names. Instead all variables/structures are passed on as values or pointers where useful.    The module contains a summary of how to tune the module for any drone specific  as well as links to the respective theoretic background. The airframes are added to the TU Delft config and 'tagged' for successful flight on PPRZ Master(last Friday).    All feedback on form or functions is welcome. Please note that the 'hardcoded' landing functions are not removed yet  this will be done in a future pull request together with the authors/users of those files.

Title: tools airframe_editor PEP8 and Python 3

Title: swarm add formation control for rotorcraft
Body: Based on Ewoud Smeur (INDI) and Hector Garcia de Marina (Formation  control) work. See  https://blog.paparazziuav.org/2017/12/02/pilot-a-super-rotorcraft  - several UAV can be control from the ground (using a joystick for    instance) by sending proper acceleration setpoint to the INDI guidance    controller  - configuration of the formation is done from a JSON file (2 example    files provided)  Some extra changes:  - update accel from IMU in GPS passthrough INS  - add accel setpoint to ABI messages  - by to accel setpoint in INDI guidance  - send ground reference from natnet2ivy  - possibility to have a joystick labeled 'GCS' with input2ivy

It can also have a bit of developer information  tutorials and so on.  Main benefit is to keep in sync the most important part of the doc with the actual code and features of paparazzi.    What do you think about the general idea and the proposed organization of the files for this doc ?

Title: radio rewrite the Spektrum driver to be generic
Body: This is based on #1799 and replace it.  Now  the normal UART driver is used instead of the specific code. It  makes it possible to use on only arch  including ChibiOS.  Binding is also possible  but for boards using ChibiOS and SD logger  it  is recommanded to disable it for the binding process as the LSE clock  required by the RTC is longer to start (bind pulses should be issued  before 200ms after power up).  The configuration is backward compatible and some defines in the boards'  header could be even removed. Only Apogee  Chimera and Elle0 have been  updated as it is the only board tested for now. There is no harm to keep  the old defines.

Title: add i2c transaction cue to the linux arch
Body: This adds a thread to read/write i2c transactions so that they don't block the main thread. This should address #1500. I currently have a hard sleep in the i2c thread of 5us  let me know if this is appropriate. Of course the transactions will not come in too fast but you also don't want too much latency.

Title: Added Relative Localization Module
Body: The module "relativelocalizationfilter" is added. This module uses an EKF that processes Bluetooth messages between drones (as enabled by the rssi + stdma modules) in order to provide relative localization between two or more drones. The stdma module is also added in this commit.  The method is as introduced and used in the paper: M. Coppola  K.N. McGuire  K.Y.W. Scheper  G. C.H.E. de Croon  "On-board Communication-based Relative Localization for Collision Avoidance in Micro Air Vehicle teams"  2017.  Configuration files for use with teams of ARdrones or pocketdrones are also included.

Title: rotorcraft update yaw to arm
Body: Somehow the yaw to arm was broken  there was quite a bit of strange behavior.    With this  you give a side stick to arm the motors  this will start the motors at minimum speed. Your stick controls will not be fed through to the controller till you return the stick to the center. When disarming  you reduce the throttle to minimum and give full side stick till the motors stop. You first have to return the stick to center before you can re-arm.    I also add an explicit autopilot_set_in_flight(false) command when starting the motors. This is not strictly necessary since the in_flight check checks if the throttle is retarded but I think this is nice just in case the in_flight code is changed in the future.

Title: CV Improve timing stability
Body: Here I tried to remove some mallocs and frees and only do them when the image sizes have changed.     Moving the timing from the start to the end of the cv computation loop helps the timing of the loop when the computational time is varying.    I also made the requested frequency of the bottom camera settable with MT9V117_TARGET_FPS. It is more efficient to limit the speed with this rather than with OPTICFLOW_FPS if no other processes are using the bottom camera.    Running the main loop at double the ap frequency seems more appropriate than the arbitrary 1000Hz that was there before. This is now also settable using the POLLING_PERIOD define.    Lastly  there is an interesting program on the bebop (2) called ephemerisd. When the parrot dragon software is running it uses about 2% of the cpu but once paparazzi is launched it jumps to 50%. I am not entirely sure what this program does or why it uses to much processing. If you Google ephemeris you get something with GPS satellite tables so I think it is safe to say that if you are flying inside you can safely close this program. For now I put it inside of an i#f PRIMARY_GPS == GPS_DATALINK. Let me know if you have a better protection check.

Title: Solving problems flying with optical flow
Body: In the current master version  vertical velocity is also determined by the optical flow module  with the help of divergence. However  the current code is not robust - leading to faulty large altitude estimates and very large velocities. This leads to large control inputs  which result in worse vision  which result in even worse estimates... you get the drift.    So  in this pull request  I just changed some things in the bebop2_opticflow.xml (it was set not to update sonar on AGL  etc.) and the opticflow_module.c files to make the hover mode work again out of the box (this was broken due to the addition of the vertical velocity).     In the future  this pull request should be followed up by a more fundamental solution that takes the reliability of the divergence into account for estimating the vertical velocity well. For now  though  this pull request will allow people to fly with optical flow again.

Title: added agl estimator when assuming non flat ground
Body: Typically  in the Vertical Float Filter  the sonar is assumed to always be correct and is used to estimate the baro offset from the ground altitude  this is only true when we assume that the ground is flat with no obstacles. This PR proposes that if so defined by the user  the filter can be inversed allowing the VFF to estimate the obstacle height from the difference between the baro and sonar measurements allowing the vehicle to fly at constant barometric altitude over obstacles. The sonar measurements help to filter the barometer measurements and provide more consistent vertical speed estimates. This filter has already been test flown in an obstacle filled environment to good effect.  One observed side effect is that the barometric pressure in an environment changes over time which would cause the vehicle to have a biases altitude. To fix this I propose to augment the Kalman filter with an additional state to estimate both the sonar and barometer offset using time scale separation  fast changes in sonar alt are likely obstacles but time averaged readings are likely the ground truth (pun intended) and should be added as a baro offset. I will implement and test this shortly. Any feedback is appreciated.

Title: xbee_api fixedwing LPC21 xbee_api broken
Body: - interrupts not enabled during xbee setup (which is called from modules_init)   - thereby only the first byte is sent (in LPC: the tx-complete interrupt loads the next byte)   - and configuration fails     - moving modules_init() after the interrupts solves this   - it is unclear how much this will break elsewhere.

Title: generator Qt project generator
Body: Add a Qt Creator project Generator for a specific AC. This can either be done trough commandline by using:  ``` make -f Makefile.ac AIRCRAFT=MyAircraftName ap.qt ```  Or automatically on each build by setting the following environment variable:  ``` export PAPARAZZI_QT_GEN=1 ```  After the creation of a project you can open Qt Creator and then Select `File->Open Project`. Then browse to the paparazzi folder and open the `ap.creator` file(Or `nps.creator`  `fbw.creator` if you want a different target). You don't need to reload/reopen Qt Creator if you use the Auto switch on each build as your project will automatically update.  Some feature additions would be: - [ ] Add the modules xml files from the airframe file - [ ] Add compile/upload configurations automatically to the creator file - [ ] Add code style to the creator file - [ ] Add a button to Paparazzi center to execute a switch to a new AC

Title: Parrot Disco stage 1 of fixes added
Body: Outcome: Full PPRZ support for Parrot Disco. Test Disco with firmware v1.7.1    Stage 1 is a well flying Disco with lots of options    - [x] Add correct Airspeed driver  - [x] Add bottom cam  - [x] Add full example Disco airframe  - [x] Test sonar at least does something reasonable  - [x] Measure idle amps  - [x] measure full throttle amps  - [x] Make sure picture bottom cam works  - [x] Test Auto1 with RC steering  - [x] Test Magneto  calibrate outside    Full Auto2 flights of minimum 1 hour total airtime with firmware 1.7.1    Stage 2 will contain more nice to haves like First inital frontcam workings  Stage 3 will be the final stage with HW X264 encoding and hardware accelerated video stabilization    For this a separate PR will be made.

Title: Image undistortion for fisheye lenses
Body: I have added undistortion functions to the vision library. These can be used to convert image coordinates from distorted fisheye lenses to undistorted coordinates and back  taking into account the camera calibration matrix and the distortion of the specific lens. The distortion function is the one from Dhane  P.  Kutty  K.  & Bangadkar  S. (2012). A generic non-linear method for fisheye correction. International Journal of Computer Applications  51(10). (invertible fisheye model)  as it is an invertible model.     I also made a module  undistort_image  that uses the functions to undistort a whole image. This is quite a slow process  so it is not really advisable to use this in a vision pipeline leading to control. However  it can be used to find the right undistortion parameter k  and shows that the undistortion functions work.    I have tested the functions and module on a Bebop 2  using the front image. I added a specific airframe to the TU Delft airframes for this purpose.

Title: Fixes RC lost status for failsafe types of RX with SBus out

A flyaway also less likely with this fix  if AUTO2 set on RC loss. Else RC loss was available but not detected  steering not possible in manual/auto1  Some defines in radio_control.h re-definable for more timeout flexibility.

Title: mission add support for custom mission patterns or actions
Body: Specific navigation functions or even payload actions can be registered in the mission module in order to be called from the mission controller like the built-in navigation patterns.    Each custom element (callback function) is registered/called with an unique string identifier of 5 char max. A maximum of 12 parameters can be passed to the callback function.    An example is provided with the nav_flower navigation function.

Title: Derotate flow front camera
Body: Derotation is also needed when using flow from the frontal camera. However  a simple correction factor applied to the median flow will not work for broad field-of-view lenses such as the Bebop 2 lens. The best way then  is to undistort and derotate individual vectors. This is what I implemented in this pull request. The parameters for the undistortion are stored in the camera-specific file and can hence be set in the airframe file.

Title: Added Disco camera support and more fixes
Mekf Wind INS
Body: This new module is a full INS including wind estimation based on IMU/GPS/baro + airspeed/AoA/Sideslip measurements with MEKF filter.  The integration is using the C++ Matrix library Eigen included as a submodule.    Some minor changes:  - airspeed and incidence sensors using ABI  - improve some drivers and system configuration  - example airframe  tested in flight    Reference:  Martin Brossard  Jean-Philippe Condomines  Silvre Bonnabel. Tightly coupled navigation and wind estimation for mini UAVs. AIAA GNC 2018  AIAA Guidance  Navigation  and Control Conference  Jan 2018  Kissimee  United States.  https://hal-enac.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01814261

Title: Ransac
Body: Added an easy wrapper around the pprz_svd_solve_float method  called fit_linear_model  to which you can pass a 1D target array and a 2D array of n_samples x Dimension for making a linear fit.    Around this linear fit function  I also made a random sample consensus method (RANSAC)  which is a robust way of doing the linear fit. The fit will then still give good results for a modest number of outliers.

Title: Snake gate detector
Body: This pull request is part of an effort to get all autonomous drone race code into the master of paparazzi  so that anyone can fly the code that we made for the IROS 2016 and 2017 autonomous drone races. The code allows a Parrot Bebop drone to detect racing gates and pass through a sequence of them at a reasonably high speed (1.8 m/s).     This first pull request contains two things:  1. The snake gate detector code  which is a computationally efficient method to find (close-to) square gates in an image.  2. A cv_detect_gate module  which runs the snake gate detector  allows to tune the color filter parameters  and allows to play with various other parameters of the snake gate detection.

Title: Spektrum rewrite
Body: This is a total rewrite of the Spektrum satellite parser  which also include support for DSMX! Protocol information is available at http://www.spektrumrc.com/ProdInfo/Files/Remote%20Receiver%20Interfacing%20Rev%20A.pdf  Things that need to be done before merging: - [ ] Add more satellites to xml makefile section of module - [ ] Fix UART ports in all board files - [ ] No guessing of TX type when RX sends type - [ ] Enable settings for binding pulses and bind at boot (or live when power can be reset or RX) - [ ] Binding at boot function - [ ] Fix sim/NPS RC - [ ] Test with different RX/TX.

Title: Gate pose estimator
Body: Next step in bringing the autonomous drone race code into master: figuring out the position of the drone relative to the gate. The PnP solver is in principle generic  but is for now only used in conjunction with the gate detection. Some additional math functions were necessary  these have been added as well.

Title: Added support for encrypted pprzlink
Body: Paparazzi side  see [#65](https://github.com/paparazzi/pprzlink/pull/65) for details.    The intention was to hide all the crypto from the user  so there is the same Paparazzi code for normal and encrypted version of pprzlink.    ## Changes    - bump pprzlink  - added `secure transparent telemetry` module  - I merged and rebased latest master  so it kind of clutters the PR    ## For reviewers  - please see comments in the code    **NOTE**: as is it shouldn't be used for any application where security is important (the key exchange part of the crypto algorithm is still missing and we are using fixed keys ATM).

Title: Autogenerate communication keys only when needed
Body: I need to generate keys upon each airframe build for the encrypted link communication.    This change does the job (edit in the Makefile.ac)  the keys are generated only when I have the [transparent_secure_telemetry](https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/blob/master/conf/modules/telemetry_transparent_secure.xml) module enabled.    @gautierhattenberger or @flixr - any comments on this solution? I don't like the duplicity in the Makefile  but I don't know how else do the conditional generation.

Title: Test with Matrix C library
Body: I want to test the C++ support for actually including C++ code. Indeed the compilation works fine if I *dont* use any C++ code  but that is not very helpful.    I am using a demo module with code borrowed from PX4/Matrix library https://github.com/PX4/Matrix - eventually I might want to use this code in `sw/ext` but for now lets assume this is OK (just ignore the files)    When I compile this code (AggeAir conf / Iris airfame) it fails at the linker script with:  ```  /usr/bin/../lib/gcc/arm-none-eabi/5.4.1/../../../../arm-none-eabi/lib/armv7e-m/softfp/libc.a(lib_a-sbrkr.o): In function `_sbrk_r':  sbrkr.c:(.text._sbrk_r+0xc): undefined reference to `_sbrk'  /usr/bin/../lib/gcc/arm-none-eabi/5.4.1/../../../../arm-none-eabi/lib/armv7e-m/softfp/libc.a(lib_a-abort.o): In function `abort':  abort.c:(.text.abort+0xa): undefined reference to `_exit'  /usr/bin/../lib/gcc/arm-none-eabi/5.4.1/../../../../arm-none-eabi/lib/armv7e-m/softfp/libc.a(lib_a-signalr.o): In function `_kill_r':  signalr.c:(.text._kill_r+0x10): undefined reference to `_kill'  /usr/bin/../lib/gcc/arm-none-eabi/5.4.1/../../../../arm-none-eabi/lib/armv7e-m/softfp/libc.a(lib_a-signalr.o): In function `_getpid_r':  signalr.c:(.text._getpid_r+0x0): undefined reference to `_getpid'  collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status  ```    What I gathered from the web  it has something to do with libraries not being in the right order. @flixr you mentioned that g++ somehow reorders libraries  can we tell the linker which order it should use?    For ChibiOS (AggieAir conf/ Minion Lia) this fails with:  ```  g++: error: unrecognized command line option '-mthumb'  ...  arm-none-eabi-gcc: fatal error: no input files  ```    Here is where the cpp files should be included: https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/blob/cpp_support/conf/Makefile.chibios#L207 but I am not sure how to specify them - @gautierhattenberger ? Also I believe that some flags will have to be modified.

Title: Pullrequest relative localization no north filter
Body: Added a relative localization filter that does not require the drones to have knowledge of a common heading (such as North). This allows to be independent of errors coming from the magnetometer or the building bias that may be caused by a gyroscope. The filter is as implemented and used in van der Helm et al. "On-board Range-based Relative Localization for Micro Aerial Vehicles in indoor Leader-Follower Flight". https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.07171.

Title: Supervision tools
Body: The purpose of this PR is to move the tools configuration (partially) out of the control_panel.xml.  The default tool configuration will be in individual files (one for each tool) in conf/tools/.  You can then override the default configuration in your control_panel.xml (eg. to change the default arguments or add custom tools). You can also add the `blacklisted="true"` attribute to the tools in your control_panel.xml to hide it in the paparazzi center.    This way  you will be able to see the new tools without changing your control_panel.xml  and you can make a custom configuration without affecting the default one.

Title: generator warning when unit attribute is used in firmware section
change Chop to Clip
Body: I noticed this define called Chop the other day and I think it should be called Clip. Clip is what you would conventionally call a function which bounds a value to a range (e.g. https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.clip.html). This should help people to find  and reuse this function in the future.

Title: Corroded Paparazzi
Body: This is a tracking PR for my efforts of bringing Rust to Paparazzi. Why is this useful? Besides being an interesting demonstration of technology  the main benefit is that Rust brings high level language abstraction (types  traits  generics) into embedded world without the need of garbage collection. Since Rust is memory safe  we don't have to worry (at least not too much) about using heap for data allocation/deallocation. Rust is also fast (zero-cost abstraction  no GC)  so performance is comparable with native C code. And the Rust compiler checks lots of things for you  so it is harder to make a mistake. So I am hoping Rust can make writing autopilot code more productive  and also safer.    The current state is:   - Rust's allocator is backed by ChibiOS's API for heap allocation/deallocation  - Simple rust module is being called     TODO:  - better way of building the rust libraries (currently I need to call `xargo` separately  not sure yet how to wrap it into the build system)  - create a paparazzi-compatibility Rust crate that has the relevant C calls (for state/control etc)    The goal is to create a new autopilot (similar to the "static autopilot") with perhaps some new cool control system that is easier to create in Rust.    I am looking for early feedback. @gautierhattenberger

Title: Local Position Estimator
Body: Based on #2328 I am putting this PR here for discussion.  This is an old attempt to copy the Local Position Estimator (INS) from Pixhawk into Paparazzi. Back in time I didn't have C++ support  now it would be much nicer with Eigen. LPE uses lidar and sonar data on top of (optional) GPS to be used for sub-meter precision.    If I remember it right   the performance was comparable with the other INS's  but I am not sure if it was actually great.    Anybody interested in polishing this or using it?

Note  some of the components of the BAT message have been removed as they were already contained in the (ROTORCRAFT_)NAV_STATUS messages.    I tested this in sim  nps and on a bebop but this will need a thorough review before merging. I look forward to your comments!

Title: Restructure bebop camera settings and ISP
Body: This is my effort at completing #2180. I implemented the changes that were made there (that I believed to be correct) as well as the recommended preset resolutions (VGA  720p  1080p and full resolution).    One of the changes was in how the camera settings were used  I built upon these suggestions and updated the settings. Now the user only sets the output resolution  image zoom and centre offsets and the rest is computed to generate a good output.    As the isp can only be used with the bebop  I moved the isp files to the bebop board folder.    In the process of doing this I realised that the documentation for the bebop cameras was quite poor and decided to make a module for the bebop cameras so that the settings can be auto documented. This results in an additional module to include in the airframe. To make this a little easier I changed all video_thread includes in bebop airframes to bebop_cam (which autoloads video_thread  plz let me know if you disagree or have an alternative).    There are also some miscellaneous changes that I found while implementing the upgrades (e.g. a setting for camera with the bebop_ae_awb even though it explicitly only works with the front camera).    Apologies for another large PR but I think that this simplifies and clarifies the camera usage for the bebop.

Title: python added explicit pyhton2 binding where ambiguous
Body: Many python scripts in paparazzi are not designed to run on python3 yet have shebang lines with simply python. If a user computer has python3 as default this will cause many scripts (including parrot_utils.py) to not work. This PR makes all scripts default to python2.    I also added a simple script to try to identify which scripts might not be python3 compatible for when we will try to upgrade the scripts.    I also tried to update some print functions to python3 using the suggestions from 2to3.    Please advise if any of these files are known to actually be fully functional under both versions and I will revert those files before merging.

Title: Fixed ACT corner bug
Body: ACT corner used to increment the number of agents looking for corners in case of little texture. It had a maximum of 1000 agents  while the fast 9 corner structure array was only 512 long. So  after long periods of little texture  the ACT corner file would write outside the memory  causing troubles with video capturing. Easy to find bug  which has now been removed.

Title: Autonomous Drone Race 2018 Code
filter IMU prefiltering using the One Euro filter
Body: One Euro filter is a very simple adaptive low pass filter that can efficiently remove the noise from the gyros and accelerometers without adding to much lag.  As it is a separated module connected to the ABI bus  it can be used with any IMU and AHRS/INS combination by selecting the correct data source for the estimation filters.    The plot below shows the recording of the roll gyro  with the blue line the original noisy signal while the red line is the filtered value. The noise level is much lower but their is almost no lag during fast rotations.  ![gyro_time_one_euro](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/452802/55314020-861f2c80-5469-11e9-92c8-3357114434e2.jpg)    The FFT of the above signal shows the noise from the motors between 150 and 200 Hz that is almost completely removed.  ![gyro_fft_one_euro](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/452802/55314246-080f5580-546a-11e9-8d12-2957f1b219f0.jpg)    This filter is very cheap in terms of computation and also very easy to tune with only two parameters.  See http://cristal.univ-lille.fr/~casiez/1euro/ for more details.

Title: Pullrequest bluegiga stdma dongle
Body: This tool allows Bluegiga dongle to communicate using STDMA (Self-organized Time-Division Multiple Access). Using this  drones with a Bluegiga USB Bluetooth dongle can communicate with eachother and exchange their RSSI (i.e.  signal strength  which in a lot of cases can be used as a measure of distance). This has been tested with up to 3 ARDrones.

Title: Ins invariant gps heading
Body: This is a modification of the invariant INS filter to use the GPS heading as a pseudo magnetometer (which is the same for ahrs_dcm filter in fact). The benefit is that you can fly without mag (which is pretty sensitive to calibration) but it is then not possible to estimate the drift with wind.  An other small change is the bounding of the accel scale factor estimation (coef `as`). Previously a very low value was stopping the filter to prevent a division by zero  even in flight. Now  the min/max values are just bounded to reasonable values.    It is also fixing a bug when checking the GPS ID for secondary receiver. The side effect of this bug was that gps heading was the true heading whatever the configuration.    This code have been tested in flight.

Title: Created a default Bebop aircraft using optitrack and full INDI

Control effectiveness values have been determined by using the adaptive INDI during test flights on 2 different bebops.  2. Added a session in the TU Delft userconf which is suitable for flight with joystick and optitrack.

Title: TU Delft MAVLab course 2019
Body: This pull request contains all changes for this year's MAVLab course  which was given in February.    In short:  - Two example airframes:    - orangeavoid: uses waypoints for navigation    - orangeavoid_guided: uses body-frame guidance commands. Could potentially be used without OptiTrack (not tested). Uses a front-camera green detector to stay within the flight area.    - Camera defines have been updated after #2364. The color detector has been re-tuned afterwards.    - All aircraft are test-flown and tagged.  - New joystick confs:    - sm600.xml: for the new usb transmitters in the lab. Still a bit buggy sometimes  but flyable.    - turnigy  xbox  - The orange avoider is updated and separated into two modules: a colored object detector and an avoidance module. The modules communicate over ABI. The avoidance logic has been moved from the airframe to the avoidance module to make to code easier to understand and adapt. (All credit goes to @kirkscheper for this one).  - opencv_bebop is updated to 3.4.5 and now also includes the contrib modules. OpenCV is now also compiled for NPS  so that the same configuration is used in the sim as on the real drone.  - video_capture has been updated to capture image sequences in addition to still frames.  - file_logger has been partially rewritten for readability.  - A python script is added to measure the flown distance of an aircraft. This script can be run on any pc as long as it's connected to OptiTrack (thanks @dewagter and Shushuai Li).    The course documentation can be found here: https://tudelft.github.io/coursePaparazzi/

Title: parrot improve bebop scripts
Body: Old shell scripts are removed and replaced by python script similar to ardrone2.  It is possible to:  - install and remove the autostart and network scripts  - configure autostart mode  - configure network to join a wifi router (with DHCP only)  - it is no longer need to modify the pprz.conf file before sending it to the drone  - the security options (AMODE) are not handled yet (not sure what are the valid options here  can be improved in the future)    This have been tested on Bebop2  hopefully for all possible combinations.

Title: Filtering option added to SDP3X airspeed sensor

Title: Created a default Bebop aircraft using opticflow and full INDI
Body: The bebop aircraft is able to follow waypoints relative to its starting position  without the use of GPS.The drift should to be around 0.25-0.5m per minute of flight time.  In addition to the creation of the aircraft and airframe  some additional  changes have been made:    1. Bebop camera calibration has been performed  2. Explicit rounding has been added to ins_int velocity estimate callback. This is necessary to prevent a bias towards a location of 0 when flying at low speeds.  3. An additional flight plan has been created. This flightplan is very similar to conf/flight_plans/rotorcraft_optitrack.xml   except for the removal of the "wait GPS" block  which prevents an airframe without GPS from compiling. This is significant code duplication  if there is a better way to fix this  please let me know.    The commit history is quite a mess  due to many tests  so squashing the commits would be very much appreciated.

Title: Collective tracking control
Body: This code is quite old  and I polished it a bit.     It is the implementation of a tracking algorithm coming from this paper https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.00182 .    I have written some instructions in the wiki https://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/Module/collective_tracking_control    For sure I am missing documentation. To be honest  I forgot exactly all the necessary doc items. So  if you do not mind  just tell me what is missing :P.    The "attached" Python simulation to tune the gains quickly is hardcoded for three aircraft + target. One day I should make it more general... but I believe it is easy to modify it by somebody if (s)he is interested in the algorithm.

Title: Refresh WMM data for 2020 to 2025
Body: With help of the COF file from https://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/geomag/WMM/soft.shtml  updated data.    Great care was taken that all data is moved to the array correctly.  It would be really good someone else **revalidates** the tables.    Since the tables are build exactly like in 2010 2015 but ordering of field was **never validated** compared to the use of g1  g2 in the **source code** my me.    It would be a **must** IMHO to make sure the field coefficients ordering in the array are correct in the first place since the WMM.COF file does not have much of a description of fields...    - [ ] Re-validated table correctness by 2nd person  - [ ] Validated array field ordering correctness by 2nd person    Based on this file [WMM2020COF.zip](https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/files/4107238/WMM2020COF.zip)    _it is a dirty job but someone has to do it ;)  then we are off the hook for 5 years again..._

Title: Dynamic grid in rectangle surveys New flight_plan feature
Body: This edit allows the user survey a rectangle and change the sweep width (grid argument) without restarting the survey. Care was taken to preserve backwards compatibility with calling the periodic rectangle survey function with two waypoint arguments. This means that all the old flight_plans can still be compiled without edit.    This new feature can also be examined by using the new flight plan directive as such...    <survey_rectangle_dynamic wp1="p1" wp2="p2" grid="var_grid" orientation="NS"/>    This would use the variable var_grid as the sweep argument. If we adjust the var_grid in the middle of our survey  the survey will not be interrupted. Instead the updated argument will be used with the subsequent periodic calls to the survey rectangle function.    This appears to work with rotor crafts  fixed wings  and with either orientation.

Title: Wls update
Body: I wrote a test for the WLS control allocation and found a mistake with the initialization of one of the arrays. The fix gives the correct result in the test  but is not flight tested.    Something else  but related:  I also realized that the use of Variable Length Arrays (VLA) leads to a lot more assembly code than fixed size arrays  and in this case it is not really needed if you call the algorithm with arguments of the same size. (Usage example: https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/blob/master/sw/airborne/firmwares/rotorcraft/stabilization/wls/wls_alloc.c#L109)  I think that only if you would have two constrained least squares problems of different size to solve it could make sense to do it like this. Should we restrict it to 'single use' in order to make it faster?

Title: Add software I2C
Body: This PR adds software-driven I2C in addition to the existing hardware I2C drivers. This allows I2C to be used on arbitrary GPIO pins at a limited bitrate (approx. 15kbps). The software I2C code is completely non-blocking and platform-independent. Software-I2C (softi2c0  softi2c1) can transparently replace the existing I2C peripherals.    I2C writing has been tested with a logic analyzer. Reading has not been tested yet because I do not have the necessary tools at home.    Since this pull requests also makes minor changes to the existing I2C code (use of function pointers to allow mixing of multiple I2C architectures)  careful review and testing of existing airframes would be highly appreciated.    This PR is part of upcoming support for the Eachine Trashcan ([WIP](https://github.com/tomvand/paparazzi/tree/trashcan_spi_cc2500_pr)) and the bitcraze flowdeck.

Title: Add chirp code sys_id_chirp module
Body: This adds a chirp module - an easy way to do automated chirps maneuvers which are a great way for performing system identification. For an example of how this was used  see my [research on the DelftaCopter](http://www.imavs.org/papers/2018/IMAV_2018_paper_17.pdf) (chirp graphs are at the end of the paper).    sys_id_chirp.xml and sys_id_chirp.h contain documentation but for a quick start  add the sys_id_chirp module to your airframe file and    ```<call fun="sys_id_chirp_add_values(autopilot_get_motors_on() FALSE values)">```    to the top of the ```command_laws``` section in your airframe file. Perform chirps by selecting the proper chirp settings in GCS and click "Chirp start" in the GCS strip!    A message is added for monitoring chirp during flight and automatically recognizing chirps in post-processing https://github.com/paparazzi/pprzlink/pull/96    The thing I'm not certain about: how to deal with the various axes that different aircraft have. During the chirp  the chirp signal is applied to a single actuator  but separate noise is also added to all other actuators (those specified by the user) to improve system identification. The user should be able to set the actuators to apply the chirps on in the airframe file. I opted for a define ```<define name="CHIRP_AXES" value="{COMMAND_ROLL COMMAND_PITCH COMMAND_YAW}"/>``` that has a default value in the header and can be overridden in the airframe file. This is a very flexible way since users with exotic airframes (and exotic actuator names) can specify freely the axes to work with. There is a downside: in the GCS you pick the axis to apply the chirp to. Ideally  this would be a dropdown menu with the specific axes named. Right now it's just a slider with every value corresponding to an index in the CHIRP_AXES (and values outside that range being ignored by a handler). Suggestions for how this could be improved are welcome.

Title: Aircraft generator
Body: This is a major rewrite of the build system and code generation of Paparazzi. Why ?    Because the current one looks like this: http://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/DevGuide/AircraftBuildProcess. Basically a program is called from `make`  calling more independent generator using `make` from syscalls  getting the result from stdout  or temp files  or both. And the XML configuration files are parsed several times by different tools in this process.    The idea here  is that everything related to code generation is handled by a single program. All necessary config files are passed as input  parsed all together (with module dependency resolution someday...)  then code is generated if needed. The parsing library can also be reuse by other tools such as the server or the paparazzicenter.    So what's next ?  I don't expect this code to be actually reviewed because:  - it is in ocaml  - it is in ocaml  - it is way too big    So if you want to go with this  the only way is to actually use it  and fix it if needed. It is passing the standard tests  but there are maybe some corner cases.  It should be functionally the same and should work in most cases. However  here are some changes:  - no more `submodule` allowed in airframe files  - `modules` node is still supported  but I would like to get ride of it  - some minor changes (old way still supported): `module` -> `header` in settings XML file  `ctl` not mandatory in radio files  `reverse` allowed in radio instead of swapping min/max values  ...    A nice knew addition (to be tested a bit more): you can define a PAPARAZZI_MODULES_PATH environment variable to set a list of external places where to find paparazzi modules (XML and source code).    All comments are welcome.

Title: FIX SoftI2C marking transaction complete before stop bit

Title: Eachine Trashcan support
Body: This PR adds support for the Eachine Trashcan with the following additions:  - **FrskyX SPI drivers**. Ported from betaflight. I copied the code with the least amount of editing possible to simplify later updates. RC channels work as normal  and both up- and downlink are supported in the form of a generic paparazzi serial device. I have included a module and an opentx lua script to tunnel pprzlink (up+down) over frsky to a pc. FrskyX telemetry is also available in limited form.      I have left the betaflight headers/license (GPLv3) in place to give proper credit  and added the paparazzi license where substantial code was added. Let me know if this is the right way to handle this.    - **DFU command module**. Reset the STM32F4 to DFU using a command over the USB serial line. The command is compatible with betaflight  so drones with the betaflight firmware can be flashed directly out-of-the-box. (Note that the linux serial driver may need a while to connect  and that the trashcan sometimes needs batteries plugged in due to the FPV camera current draw). The command is automatically sent when pressing upload if the module is added to the airframe.      The STM DFU bootloader is very particular about the processor state at boot  and support from OpenCM is pretty limited  so the code may look slightly hackish. Feedback welcome.    - **Trashcan board files and airframe**. Original files provided by @OpenUAS  thanks! Airframe tuning needs to follow in a later PR but the drone is flyable right now.    This PR has been lying on the shelf for a bit too long because corona made it difficult to test-fly  so I'd rather get it merged now than wait while it gets further out of sync with master. The only things I have not finished yet is the airframe  this can be tuned in a later PR. The drone flies ok right now  and I have already used this code during the development of the flowdeck drivers.

This might still be a useful change  though.

Title: effectiveness module and tool to log and process control effectiveness
Body: This is an attempt to make a generic tool to log and process data used to estimate control effectiveness.  The module part can record all commands and imu data by default  plus a number of other sensor if required (position  speed  airspeed ...).  The ground tool is able to read the data and apply a series of filters before calling the optimization to find fitting parameters. A mixing matrix can also be applied to find cross talk like for full indi). Not all sensor models are implemented yet. The process is configured with a json file.  This is not really tested  only in the case of simple indi. And I'm not completely sure of the mixing part  so @EwoudSmeur   I would appreciate your opinion on this !  Hopefully some day we won't edit the code by hand for every aircraft to tune for indi ;)

Title: Fix for gspeed spiking issue 2566
Body: Testflying to test the new uBlox M9N   FW 4.03 set to High rate ~12Hz with 4 constellations TOGETHER :) gave this issue. Investigate and culprit is (see ublox M9 datasheet) gspeed message is now in mm/s not in cm/s for the new PVT mesages  old are VEL are in cm/s.    Anyhow a small change fixed it     Flight before fix:  ![BeforeFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/483944/90314478-59f83480-df14-11ea-8eef-72e1766d7368.png)    Flight after fix:  ![AfterFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/483944/90314481-61b7d900-df14-11ea-85ac-639da7e90d02.png)    BTW: In same run set the HMSL_BIT value immediately after when there is a HSML..

Title: fixed ref reset on mode switch heading issue
Body: Upon some mode switches  the reference attitude is reset to the current attitude. A quaternion is made from the current attitude in euler angles  but for this a 'pitch-corrected' heading is used (a heading that points in the same direction if you pass 90 deg pitch. This is a problem  because if interpreted as a normal ZYX euler angle set the reference attitude is incorrectly set. The result is a 180 yaw movement when switching between FWD and ATT with pitch < -90 deg. The real unedited ZYX euler angles should be used instead.    Actually  looking at it again  should the ref psi be reset at all? Ref phi and theta are also not reset...

Title: Module for transparent control of external GPIOs
Body: This PR adds a new module that can redirect calls to gpio functions to other modules  providing *transparent* access to gpio pins on expansion ICs (e.g. PCA9534).    Unfortunately the current paparazzi code makes calls directly to the libopencm3 gpio functions without any HAL inbetween  so I had to use some gcc magic to wrap those functions. This is a bit hacky and will probably not port to other compilers.    I have tested the gpio_setup_output and gpio_toggle functions and these seem to work well. (Tested on Trashcan STM32F4 with softI2C to PCA9536).    I have renamed the pca95x4 peripheral to pca95xx  as it is also compatible with the pca953**6** that I am using.

Title: Fix settings in log
Body: [log] add the latest generated settings if available to log file            This way  the exact order of the settings used during the flight might      be available.      The only false case would be to start a server  rebuild and aircraft      with different parameters or target  then flash and start the plane. In      this case  there is no guarantee that the information is correct.      However  this is the best we can do  since we can't know when starting      the server with which target the aircraft will be used.            close #2563    Also fix the log replay

Title: Protect quat to euler conversion for NaN
Body: If the state quaternion is slightly off around +-90 degrees pitch  the result  might be a NaN if the asin is computed. I added bounds to make sure this  can never happen. The argument should not be outside [-1 1] anyway.

Title: GVF Parametric
Body: This is a "big" commit.     We have extended the notion of the GVF to support a bigger set of trajectories (including 3D ones).    I am almost finished with the [Wiki entry](https://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/Module/guidance_vector_field)  now I have split it into two parts: GVF implicit (the already implemented) and this new one GVF parametric. As it says in the wiki  both modules are compatible and can coexist.    It has been already tested with real flights. In fact  @mrtbrnz has tried the 3D ellipse too with one of the zaggies he told me.    Please  take your time  and whatever you do not see clear  or you want different just tell me. @gautierhattenberger you mentioned that you would like to have the "low level" control isolated? This is happening here  https://github.com/noether/paparazzi/blob/gvf_advanced/sw/airborne/modules/guidance/gvf_parametric/gvf_parametric.cpp#L317 and here https://github.com/noether/paparazzi/blob/gvf_advanced/sw/airborne/modules/guidance/gvf_parametric/gvf_parametric.cpp#L207 . Let me know whether this is okeish. In the near future  these GVFs should work with rovers and boats.    The GVF app (python) is valid for both versions implicit and parametric. However  is far from being okeish since I was patching here and there for the new GVF. It consumes a lot of resources since I have to think how to plot more efficiently (right now I think I create a new figure every iteration  and this is far from good). Suggestions are also welcome here. Nevertheless  the GVF app works ok  it is just "slow" and far from being efficient.    @EwoudSmeur   for the cyclone/hybrid  let me know which guidance signals would you like to have for a 3D trajectory. After the holidays  I would like to have the two GVFs working with a rotorcraft  so I will provide the desired 3D accelerations  but maybe for the hybrid your would like to have something different.

Title: nav selectable navigation functions from flight plan
Body: Add `nav_type` and `nav_params` attributes to the basic flight pattern instructions of the flight plan to select alternate guidance and nav functions for them.  To use it  it is just needed to provide macros or functions with the form `MyNavXxxxx` for all nav instructions like `NavCircleWaypoint` or `NavGotoWaypoint`. Then call the FP instructions like this:    ` <circle wp="WP1" radius="80" nav_type="MyNav"/>`    In this example  `MyNavCircleWaypoint` will be called instead of the default `NavCircleWaypoint`.

Title: Add e identification module

Title: GDB New gdb name for ARM
Body: In Ubuntu 18.04 or lower  ARM stuff come from the gcc-arm-embedded PPA  and GDB is invoked by `arm-none-eabi-gdb`.  In Ubuntu 20.04  ARM stuff come from official ubuntu packages with packages `gcc-arm-none-eabi` and `gdb-multiarch`. GDB is now invoked with `gdb-multiarch`.

Title: Joystick Add option to wait for an event on all axis to start
Body: Initial position of axis are unknown until an event occurs on this axis.  This PR adds the option "-c" on input2ivy to wait for an event to occurs on each axis before the program start its normal behavior (sending ivy messages).  This ensures that no false values are sent.

Title: Server modify ac_id field of CONFIG message for replay sessions
Body: During a replay session  when requested with CONFIG_REQ  the server is not consistent over the "ac_id" field.  I propose to fix it to what I think is the most logical.    When the replay starts  the server send the message `ground NEW_AIRCRAFT replay1`.  When requested by the `AIRCRAFTS_REQ` message  the server also reply with `replay1`.  In all later messages  the server use `replay1` as ac_id as well.  The only exception is that  when requested with the `CONFIG_REQ` message  the server replay with `1` as ac_id.  I think it should reply with `replay1`.    The only code I found to be affected by this change is in pprz_connect  which assume the id is an integer. Removing the cast to integer fix it  and makes a previously erroneous docstring true.    This could break external code  however  considering that `ac_id` fields in the `ground` message class are all of type string  I think that such code should be fixed anyway.

Title: SPI SD Logger updates
Body: Fixes/updates for the SPI SD logger:  - Allow arbitrary devices for download. *I have only tested this with usb serial!*  - Update sdlogger_download to pprzlink v2. Hardcoded as before  so pprzlink v1 is no longer supported...  - Reduce download chunk size to 64 bytes max. I had missing packets (not sure if buffers on the drone or on my pc are overflowing)  fixed by limiting the max number of bytes sent at once.  - ~~Remove warning from settings_xml_parse.py because it was interfering with the download program. Not sure if this is used anywhere else...~~  - Updated documentation.    The fixes are slightly hacky in places because I did not have a lot of time to work on this. Let me know if something needs to be fixed/cleaned-up.    Tested on stm32f4 (trashcan/crazybeef4fr) with the bitcraze usd-deck with a transcend 8GB class 10 MicroSDHC and with usb_serial as sdlogger downlink device. Compilation tested with Lisa Hex airframe with uart as downlink device.

Title: Tracker Fix tracker route
Fix modules and telemetry freq
Body: With the introduction of #2545  the modules and periodic telemetry prescalers was not set properly. The problem is that the correct value is only available after generating the makefile and calling "make" again (old process)  but it is not possible anymore have the information from the start  and only the default freq was used (as reported in #2537).  So  instead of a static prescaling computed by the generators  the prescaler values are now computed at compile / run time.  In terms of frequency  it should be similar to the old code as long as there is no periodic functions trying to go faster than the base frequency. It was previously reported by the generator  it won't be the case anymore. A future improvement would be to have checks at compile time eventually.  The only change I'm expecting so far  is the balancing of the functions (to avoid to have all periodic functions called in the same loop). The old way required the base frequency  so it is replaced by something slightly different that should have the same effect. However  there is no guarantee that the sequence of modules' functions will be exactly the same.    I have only tested this code in simulation at the moment  so hardware tests would be welcome.

Title: prevent RC while failsafe
Body: if RC is on and full throttle  aircraft keep landing on failsafe

Title: computer vision Opticflow multiple cameras
Body: Proposal for #1772     ~~The files currently compile  I plan to test the opticflow module on a Bebop with both cameras before finalizing the pull request.~~   The modified `cv_opticflow` module is able to run the computer vision functions on both front and bottom camera simultaneously. I tested it on a Bebop 1  I added the required defines to the `bebop_opticflow_indoor.xml` airframe to showcase the module usage  but perhaps making a whole new airframe might be better.    I have not found a clever solution on how to avoid writing a lot of duplicate code for the defines in `cv_opticflow.xml` (and as a consequence in the initialization of the multiple `opticflow_t` structs). Originally I intended for the module to be able to run on an arbitrary number of cameras  but due to how Paparazzi handles module defines I had to hardcode it to front and bottom cameras only in a lot of places.    There are a lot of changes that have been made already  the next step would be to change the opticflow ABI message  since (from my understanding) it's not currently possible to distinguish if the message contains results from the front or the bottom camera.

I have tested that the code is running on a Tawaki board. Only compiled the other boards.    I have olse dropped a few boards:  - discovery: there is a support of the nucleo144 with F7 for people testing on breakout boards  - VMS ECU: not sure this project is still running or using this code  @podhrmic if yes  I can add it back  no problem  - XVert: I'm not even sure it ever worked and the frame is not produced or sold

Title: ocaml fix SRTM download path
Body: SRTM data are no more available for direct download  using ESA data  instead. The new SRTM data are SRTM3 GL1 (1 arcsec instead of 3  previously)  so the code is now adapted to support both formats   the most accurate available will be used first.  The only way to force the update of new files is to remove the previous  ones from data/srtm folder.    close #2642

Title: Survey rectangle with No Go area
Body: Here is a first shot implementation at a rotorcraft rectangle survey with a user-defined no-go zone. The no go zone is defined with two way points (like the rectangle). The survey will map the whole area  while not considering this area in its survey. I have also attached an example flight plan to run with.    This is not fully complete  but is probably an experimental feature. The things that are left to do...       1. Assure that the no-go zone is not violated by the u-turns between runs (possibly by shrinking the valid survey size)       2. Assure that the no-go zone is not violated by the travel between partial surveys (possibly done by defining the navigation  path between surveys.

Title: Added log name argument to server ml
Body: I wanted to be able to name the output files of the server  so I added a cmd line argument to server.ml for this purpose. The timestamp previously used is still used if no name is provided. If a name is provided  the timestamp will be added to the string...    For example  the command...    ./server -log_name ardrone2    ... Will produce the files...    ardrone2__DATE__TIME.data and ardrone2__DATE__TIME.log    I am not very experienced with ocaml  so please feel free to suggest another way to do this.    Best   Jack

Title: tests add a compilation test node to modules
Body: When adding a test node to a makefile section  with required compilation  flags  include and other options  all the files (not arch dependent  files) can be compiled with a TAP compatible program  included in the  standard tests of the CI servers.  Not all module's XML files are converted  but a large part of the most  important parts are already covered. More will be added later. The  number of tested airframes (full compilation of all targets) have been  reduced to speed the CI compile time but still covers the relevant  architecture and boards.  The main benefit is that the overall coverage is already better than  before as previous test aircraft were compiling more or less the same  part of the airborne code  while this new mechanism is more efficient to  test modules not included in any config.

Title: indi_simple Fixed rate feedback filter and initialisation
Body: Before it did not matter if the rate filter was enabled  since every loop the body rates were copied to the rates_filt_fo in the loop itself.  Now the rates_filt_fo is defined and copied from the bodyrates in the initialisation phase as a global variable. If the filter is enabled around any of the body axis (p q r) a first order filter will be applied using the rates_filt_fo from the previous iteration. If the filter is disabled the rates_filt_fo will be copied form the body_rates at that timestep.

Title: modules ocaml implement module dependency
Body: - support depends  conflicts and provides nodes  all under a 'dep' node  - autoload are kept for now and are not moved yet  - modules are updated for new dep format  - it is now required that module's name and filename are the same  - order of loaded modules are respecting the dependency relations (in particular in the init sequence)    Other modules that may require dependencies will be update eventually later. The proposed modifications should be fully compatible with current airframe files.

This might be due to the fact it is currently pointing to an ID that is neither a tag or a branch.  With this we stick to the closest release tag  3.3.9  so only 3 commits back. Changes after that are related to sparse matrix that we don't use.  Of course  this may not be the source of error  but still worth trying it I think.

Title: Reorganize INDI simple for better takeoff
Body: With INDI simple  there was still the possibility to turn off the control just by giving a low thrust command. With these changes  you also have to be not in_flight and instead the increments are not accumulated  so you end up with a proportional controller.    I reorganized some of the code to implement this

Title: Allow rapid re arming after kill
Body: Sometimes  a drone can be accidentally killed in flight. Re-arming often takes  too long and the drone it crashes. This would be avoided if after kill  the  drone can rapidly re-arm by unkilling.    Maybe someone should shed his/her light on the robustness of this implementation. Personally  I don't like that autopilot_arming_set() could be called from anywhere to mess up the state machine due to different causes. Can this function be removed entirely?

Title: Feature accurate cpu load
Body: We used CH_DBG_THREADS_PROFILING to get cpu load information  but this chibios module is deprecated  not accurate  and forbid use of scheduler tickless mode.    This PR introduce the usage of CH_DBG_STATISTICS which is :    CPU cycle precise instead of SYSTICK precise : better measure of threads that are waken often but use a small quantum of CPU time   compatible with tickless mode   take into account time spent in ISR    This PR also enable tickless scheduler mode

Title: Indi updates

Title: Enter guidance indi hybrid
Body: The guidance_indi_enter function was not really implemented well. This commit resets the filters and sets the thrust level to the last value of stabilization_cmd[COMMAND_THRUST].

Title: fix correct ADC buffer offset for ChibiOS
Body: - with ChibiOS 20.3 the half buffer starting position is computed by    hand and was wrong in this case: it should be the product of the half    buffer size by the number of channels  - some other minor fixes:    - using && instead of & in boolean comparison    - use an intermediate const variable for the number of channels to      suppress a warning (comparison always true due to limited data range)      when the number of channels is zero (no ADC in use)

Title: FIX simulation mag saturation
Body: We were using the default for the Nederdrone  but apparently saturating the mag sensor in simulation causing heading issues. I think it is not really helpful to have this saturation limit here (one would need to make a new nps_sensors h file for every sensor setup) while most of the time we're not interested in simulating this limit anyway. Would it make sense to just set it to a large value in the default?

Title: Replay settings
Body: In a replay session  settings file is not generated.  This PR generates it.  The settings updates well in the GCS.  Obviously  changing a setting won't affect it...    It seems I have reverted some 10 years old changes. Is it still relevant or not ?  https://github.com/paparazzi/paparazzi/commit/f0dcd7eceb52bb0defe5746799e9bdbd62fb9475

Title: fix correct extraction of settings empty if not found
Body: close #2765

Title: nps clean sensors params files
Body: - try to set the sensor frequency automatically at the correct value  - make more parameters configurable  - set higher bounds for all sensors to avoid saturation  - remove old unused files  - update airframe files    This is following #2764. It turns out that sensor params where completely wrong for saturation and freq  which was make simulation run wild in many situations. With this  the default file should adapt to most cases  with nearly perfect sensors. A noisy file example is kept for testing.

Title: replay Use generated settings
Body: Use "generated_settings" node instead of "settings" for replay settings.  Generate an empty node if not found.  According to #2569  "settings" node is "wrong"  so its better if its not generated for replay.    Can you try it @OpenUAS to be sure it still works for you?

Title: ins_invariant reset state position and speed properly
Body: It prevents the filter to jump to the new position  which can create a wrong estimation of the accelerometer scale bias.  Aligner is restarted if needed.    Also fix float constants and other small details.

Title: Autopilot reorg
Body: This PR is reorganizing the core autopilot `main_ap` around better defined "tasks" and harmonized between the different firmwares.    The new structure is made to guarantee a certain sequence in the init phase and between the tasks' blocks. In particular  a fixed time between some tasks can fixed: between sensor periodic and estimation periodic  between estimation and control  etc.    As a result  all modules have been updated to fit into their dedicated tasks. In addition to that  the dependencies between module in terms of actual modules or functionalities have been explicitly specified. The module generator is therefore checking that all required components are loaded. New modules automatically loaded according the current target/firmware/board have been introduced and may replace the makefiles at some point.    Some minor changes are included here like a few airframe update  unused code cleaning  fixes for warnings ...    Some work is still needed  especially concerning the actuators and radio control (due to FBW splitting) or baro (stupid "baro_board" subsystem). This can be done in a later PR  this one is already big enough...    It would be nice to do more test on real hardware. My own test are working for CI compilation  simulation  and a few real frames.

Title: Fix prevent lock of as parameter
Body: This solves a problem where the accelerometer scaling could get locked at 0.5 or 1.5 as the derivative would then be set to zero. In simulation it could reach this factor in the first seconds and then it would never change. I reported this issue in #2537     The heading drift (at least in nps) is still an open issue.

Title: Better link status
Body: Improve TELEMETRY_STATUS when multiple (redundant) links are used.  Previously  there was no way to tell if one of the links was down.  Now  it should behave as expected:  - if one of the link is down  it goes red in the Link tab. It goes orange in the strip (with correct number of links up).  - if link combiner is down  all links are shown as down (link may still be up  but no message are received)  and the indicator in the strip goes red.  - if all links are lost  they all goes red  and the indicator in the strip goes red.

Title: LinkCombiner rename function
Body: There was a typo in this function name.

Title: EKF2 Optical Flow Interface
Body: This pull request mainly concerns the extension of the EKF2 state estimation capabilities through optical flow input. The branch has been extensively tested and validated successfully. During the development also other modules have been improved. In total  this PR brings improvements on:    - ins_ekf2 module: new optical flow interface  - mateksys_3901_l0x: added rotation compensation for height + calibration strategy  - gps_datalink: used to get fake gps  now gives also fake magnetometer if selected by the user  - Nederquad: new airframe for quadrotor used at TUDelft    Added wiki on flow sensor: https://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/Module/Mateksys_3901_l0x  Added wiki on ins_ekf2: https://wiki.paparazziuav.org/wiki/Subsystem/ins#ekf2 (to be finished)

Title: Fix MPU6000 spikes in certain chipbatches
Body: On certain Flight-controller  either bad batch of MPU6000  overheat  Non clean power and whatnot max value spikes can occur. This completely messes up the IMU attitude state. those boards are unique  to expensive or not feasible to replace chip.To still be able to fly these flight-controllers an 3value median filter is added to the RAW output. Default MPU module behaviour is still the same but by adding` <define name="IMU_MPU_USE_MEDIAN_FILTER" value="TRUE"/>` to the mpu6000 module in airframe the issue is resolved with this fix  see screenshot of before and after... BTW mind the Scale  no it is not more noise... ;-)    An airframe was added to PR be able to validate and testfly the fix.    ### **Before**  ![BeforeFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/483944/128871438-3dfb38df-6464-4b26-b176-efc45b703c6f.png)    ### **After**  ![AfterFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/483944/128871480-9edd49bd-9f8c-471b-8505-7d872ffd96b2.png)

Title: Add PprzGCS tool
Body: Since we start using it  this will make things easier.

Title: ADD tilt twist control twist around z
Body: This commit implements tilt twist control for vehicles that rotate slow  in the z axis compared to the other axes (like tailsitters).    The attitude error is decomposed in a tilt and a twist part  and the  tilt error is compensated assuming that the rotation around z is zero  (very slow in comparison).    I can add the test to the other algebra tests if needed.
